0.description: I've been eating here since I was a little kid.  Most people come in for the delicious baked goods, but I prefer to eat dim sum here since the wait isn't long and the ha cao is huge!  Granted it may not be the warmest place since people are constantly opening the doors to come in, but if you love dim sum and want something quick and easy, then I would say this is the place to be,

38.description: Amazing bakery, BBQ pork buns are legit and cheap. Red bean paste anything is solid. The gals behind the counter offered samples of anything I asked about. Get a box of goodies to go, it'll run you about 12 bucks.

51.description: Cheap food, great tastes, nice laid back environment what's not to like?

27.description: Been coming here with my four year old for the last year and a half since we moved to Chicago to get our Asian bakery fix.  I grew up near San Francisco and would go to Chinatown there so I am completely familiar with amazing Asian bakeries.  This place is solid.  I usually get the steamed BBQ pork bun ($1.05) and the bun here is really good.  Best to get them in the morning when they are steamy fresh.  Their cupcake (sponge cake in a cup form) is also something I like to get... nice and soft and fluffy.  My little guy usually goes for the hot dog bun ($1.00)... he's a kid, what can you say??  Service is not spectacular but it's efficient.

32.description: The first pork i've ever eaten was from this place, and ever since then I've been hooked! This bakery is right off the Argyle red line stop (seriously! right next to it!!), which makes it easy to quickly run in and grab a dozen or so buns. Honestly, I've tried a bunch of different buns here, savory to sweet, and it's all really delicious and cheap enough that you can buy a bunch of different ones to try yourself. They don't take credit cards here, so make sure you have cash on you!

54.description: Wonderful bakery.  I had read all about the sesame bun with red bean paste and was very sceptical, but I am SO glad I decided to try it.  The sesame bun itself was like eating mom's homeade bread.  Then you reach the warm, sweet red bean paste in the middle :-) So so good.  There were a ton of other fresh cakes and goodies in their windows.  Head to China town and give this place a try.

48.description: Other than the sponge cake here, all else reeks of egg. They use too many eggs, and the pastries are too dry.  However, like I said, the sponge cakes are moist and airy.  A great snack to purchase when visiting Argyle.  Unfortunately, they're not always fresh and you can really smell the eggs.  I've had steamed pork buns, taro buns, and red bean buns as well.  The taro and red bean buns are disappointing.  The balance between bread and filling is just not right, especially when these buns are large.  As for the steamed pork buns, these are probably a better buy than the former.

44.description: Great Chinese pastries for less than a dollar a piece. I love their sweet buns. They take cash only but even a dollar can get you decent snack or breakfast.

24.description: I've been eating dumplings from here since I was little, in fact from the age of 6, currently in my mid twenties.I didn't mind the food, Taste pretty good and the pastry my mother always taken a liking to.Until recently, this week all that has changed.November 14, 2014I took my relatives here to get a repeat,  yellow pork dumpling and shrimp dumpling 30-40$ worth cash, no receipts../and some random sorts of pantry for my aunt and her family. We drove 45 minutes to get there, that's loyalty.Today however we found bugs in or dumplings, bugs... Really? Yes!19 year customer! And I went back there in good faith to show them, but the restaurant's lack of service to even apologize or do anything about it. The person looked completely unfazed. Like nothing had happen or as if I didn't even exist. You should definitely address the problem, because this is not the first time anything if this sort happened from here, but someone could have gotten sick. At least you should try to care, no longer a customer. And yes this is a huge problem, the bug was also cooked it seemed. Disgusting! Sorry but whatever 19 years has built, you destroyed in one day. Yes I will upload the picture as well.

7.description: This location is better than the one in Chinatown. Not only because the food is nicer, but the staff is friendlier too. The steamed and baked buns are the main reason to come here! Come early or they will sell out!The pastries are nice but are the same as any other Chinese bakery. They sell dim sum and it's pretty tasty! Great if you want one or two items on the go without sitting with friends and family for the whole dim sum experience. They make really tasty fresh soy milk that is lightly sweetened. It doesn't taste like any Silk product you've purchased at the grocery store, nor is it fortified with vitamins and calcium. WARNING: It is extremely hot when first made! You can burn your entire mouth! Twice if you forgot the last time it happened ;-)The cakes are light and fluffy with real whip cream and the fruit is fresh. These will make any birthday a special one for loved ones. You can make your order the same day if you call or visit in the morning and pick it up in the afternoon.THIS IS A CASH ONLY BUSINESS!

49.description: This is my go-to bakery in my short stay in Evanston (I hope to be back!).Chiu Quon also has a store in Chinatown, but this is a closer bakery to me, but still possesses the same consistency and quality! The workers helped me both in English/Cantonese (and I believe they may speak Vietnamese, too), so I enjoy the different languages that are used here.  I usually get their sesame ball, egg tarts, and sweet buns (custard, coconut, etc).  Yum! Definitely coming back here as long as I'm nearby!

40.description: Pretty much you can't go wrong here. All the baked good are amazing. The earlier you come the longer the line so be prepared to wait. It is well worth it. Highly recommended sesame pork cookie and moon cakes but really you can't go wrong with anything you pick those were just my favorites.

53.description: We decided to make a quick stop in here on an unseasonably cold and windy day to warm up and look at their bakery selection and boy am I glad we did.The interior is rather old and shabby looking but it gets the job done.  There are even several tables for customers to sit and enjoy a pastry with coffee.  Most of the patron just ordered their stuff to-go though.Their selection spans from savory to sweet and fruity and can be daunting especially if you are next in line and haven't decided what you want.  Luckily the line doesn't move very fast so you'll have plenty of time to decide and then change your mind before being asked for your order.We took our pastries with a tiny cup of super sweet watered down coffee while we thawed out from the frigid Chicago punishment that we endured outside.This is a great place to stop and relax for a few minutes while touring the Viet town area. Prices are fairly cheap but I believe they only accept cash so be prepared.

30.description: Good stuff served here that is for sure, would I say it's outsanding not really, I am from Los Angeles and we have plenty of Asian pastry shops but this one was pretty good, ordered some mini Apple pastries and the pork steam bun.The apple mini pastry was crispy and moist - delicious.The crispy ear pastry was flacky and good.The custard flat soft mini bread was different but still enjoyable.

46.description: Pretty cheap with a lot of fillings. Compared to La PatisserieP, it is much cheaper like 15-20 cents and much better with more fillings, especially the BBQ pork bun which is pretty big too...  I love all their pastries especially egg tart, coconut rolls and BBQ pork buns. Also, their soybean drinks are freshly made. The only downside is that it is a cash only place.

1.description: It was a delight stumbling upon this nice little bakery in our stroll along Chinatown. The BBQ Pork Bun was delicious! We also tried the Green Tea Mousse cake. It was yummy, not overwhelmingly sweet, soft, and had an interesting gelatinous texture to it. Also, I wish I took a photo of their cakes because they look like works of art. Cant wait to sample! Tip: bring some $$$ because they are a cash-only establishment.

55.description: There's a reason that this place is so highly rated. They won't let you down.Everything is good.For the savory, I always go for the BBQ pork bun.For the sweet,  I'm partial to the red bean filled goodies e.g. the red bean sesame ball.

9.description: I give four stars for the price and for the extensive bread selection. Individual beads range from 50 cents to 2 dollars. As for the general ambience of the bakery and the quality of the breads.. I am going to have to knock off a star. The workers are pretty reserved and they often look pissed off. The bread is okay.. but once in a while. I wouldn't want to eat it everyday like I would an almond croissant from Petes. My personal favorites are the pineapple buns (which really does not taste like pineapples), red bean buns, and the egg tarts!Not a place that I personally would go again and again, but a good place to go when visiting Argyle.

26.description: Chiu Quon has become my go-to place in Chicago for Chinese goodies.  My family has been coming here for years, and not a whole lot has changed.  The items that I consistently get are good and so cheap.  First off, I highly recommend their steamed pork buns.  For all you Wow Bao fans, these put theirs to shame!  The dough is consistent......not too soft and not too chewy.  The pork filling is nice combo of sweet and savory.  They could stand to use a little more filing, but at $1.05 each, it would be wrong for me to complain.  I also really like their "bo lo baau" which translates to pineapple bun in English.  To give you a description, it's a large bun (tastes like a roll) but topped with a sweet, sugar cookie type crust.  You can get these either plain or with a custard filling!  I do occasionally get their egg tarts, which are average.    For you dim sum fans out there, Chiu Quon also sells a lot of your favorite dim sum items (various dumplings, Chinese crepes, etc......).  I've pretty much tried everything and give my approval.  Lines can be out the door, especially on weekends, and service can be really spotty; however, you don't go to a Chinese bakery/restaurant expecting Alinea type of service.  Chiu Quon is definitely a must try for those who appreciate different kinds of bakeries and budget eaters.  Under $5 can get you a good lunch and snack for later!

25.description: When I want Chinese buns I go to two places in Argyle, and Chiu Quon is one of them.  I don't go to have my mind blown, I go to find my inexpensive, safe and dependable snack - and I stock up so I can snack on more of them later! What irks me a little about the place is that they don't always have what I'm craving all the time - but that's life.  Lately I've been craving more filling in my buns too (including from this place, at times) but everybody seems to be cutting back, and moreover the buns are kinda cheap, so you get what you pay for.Some of my personal go-to's (I haven't had their youtiao/yao tiu/crullers but on the weekends people buy dozens of them.  It's amazing but also a disturbing amount of fried food to feed your family):- Po-tat (Portuguese-style egg tarts)- Ham sui gok (fried dumplings with shrimp and pork and stuff)- Ham & cheese- Ham & green onionLastly - the mini egg tarts have a cookie crust which is really a step down from the flaky crust on the larger sized egg tarts.  Skip them and get the big ones, they're way more worth your while.

12.description: Chiu Quon has become my go-to place in Chicago for Chinese goodies.  My family has been coming here for years, and not a whole lot has changed.  The items that I consistently get are good and so cheap.  First off, I highly recommend their steamed pork buns.  For all you Wow Bao fans, these put theirs to shame!  The dough is consistent......not too soft and not too chewy.  The pork filling is nice combo of sweet and savory.  They could stand to use a little more filing, but at $1.05 each, it would be wrong for me to complain.  I also really like their "bo lo baau" which translates to pineapple bun in English.  To give you a description, it's a large bun (tastes like a roll) but topped with a sweet, sugar cookie type crust.  You can get these either plain or with a custard filling!  I do occasionally get their egg tarts, which are average.    For you dim sum fans out there, Chiu Quon also sells a lot of your favorite dim sum items (various dumplings, Chinese crepes, etc......).  I've pretty much tried everything and give my approval.  Lines can be out the door, especially on weekends, and service can be really spotty; however, you don't go to a Chinese bakery/restaurant expecting Alinea type of service.  Chiu Quon is definitely a must try for those who appreciate different kinds of bakeries and budget eaters.  Under $5 can get you a good lunch and snack for later!

59.description: BBQ pork buns for less than a dollar.  Seriously.  The taro ball is awesome, and they have many more goodies to choose from.  Besides handwritten notes in the pastry case, the menu on the wall is in Chinese so I recommend checking their website menu before heading over there. The sausage and egg bun has quail egg, not chicken so the flavor is a bit different.  Not my thing.

21.description: The place I usually like to go to was closed today... so I decided to give this one a try.  I absolutely loved their bbq pork buns!  update:  On my second visit I got a hot dog bun and a coconut cream turnover... both delicious.another update:  On today's visit I saw that they had chicken buns (which I'd seen on their menu, but never in their stock)... so, I tried 'em... and enjoyed them very much.

17.description: We like to come here after we eat pho to get some pastries to take home. We usually alwasy get some of the red bean or custard soft mochi cakes. Then we usually get some coconut buns or bbq pork buns. I had the coconut cocktail bun and it was filled a coconut custard which was tasty. We also like to get the soy milk and the dou hua (tofu pudding). This place is cheap and tasty. For 10 bucks you can have a bag full of pastries to take home and enjoy.

10.description: Good stuff served here that is for sure, would I say it's outsanding not really, I am from Los Angeles and we have plenty of Asian pastry shops but this one was pretty good, ordered some mini Apple pastries and the pork steam bun.The apple mini pastry was crispy and moist - delicious.The crispy ear pastry was flacky and good.The custard flat soft mini bread was different but still enjoyable.

5.description: Had to come check this location out after going to Chiu Quon in Chinatown and enjoying a delicious almond cookie. It was early in the morning so I wanted something breakfasty and grabbed the ham and cheese and egg bun. Warmed it up in the microwave when I got home and it was tasty. The sweet bun wraps perfectly around the salty ham and egg. The service was fast and the lady who helped me was friendly. A line started to form behind me so it sounds like I got there right on time!

3.description: Yummy yummy pastries. I can't believe I haven't written a review of this bakery yet! It's right next to the Argyle red line stop, so it's a pretty convenient location for me and I try to drop by often. They often run out of my favorite things by late afternoon, so it's best to get there early. I love the Portuguese egg tarts (creamier than the other egg tarts they have, which are also good--you can tell the Portuguese tarts apart by the slightly browned custard), sesame balls, custard bun, zongxi (wrapped sticky rice), BBQ pork bun, and pineapple bun. Make sure to bring cash!

35.description: Before going to this bakery, make it sure you have cash with you. They dont accept cards and checks. This place is a gem in ARGYLE where you can have different varieties of bread, sweet or savory. They also have small selection of dimsum and cakes! They have few tables to accommodate customers who want coffee and bread to dine in. Cakes are made to order depending on the occasion you want. You must try their steamed buns too.

19.description: For $9:1 red bean bun1 taro bun2 sesame red bean balls1 helping turnip cake (warning: contains heavy dose of pork)1 package of freshly baked rolls1 large coffeeI was a pretty happy kid swinging my bag o' baked booty as a practically skipped out the door in search of the nearest bench to lay out my loot. The best part of this was the sesame balls - perfectly oily, super fresh and dense with red bean filling. The red bean bun was exactly how it should be, and the price was a steal at 80 cents! The taro bun was a tad dull, and I had to toss the turnip cake as it contained pork BUT the bite I had was deliciously greasy! Avoid the coffee if you can, this is obviously not a place to buy coffee (it was instant) but I was desperate. The savory pastries all contain meat, but they looked downright tasty, I was tempted to eat hog again. There is a back room filled with old Chinese people having a ball. I mean, how bad can it be when you're eating Chinese pastries and drinking fresh soy milk on a Sunday morning? Good sign! Overall, this was a great Chicago Chinatown experience!Cash only.

28.description: Ok props to the store clerk here, she was actually decent and is very efficient. there was a looong line and the line never got shorter people just keeps coming in!! i was like well whats all the hype, all of a sudden i remember there is a pastry shop with this exact same name in chinatown. which was not my preferred asian bakery i liked li wen da better. but hey, there is no li wen da here so i went inside. went inside and saw a sign that says cash only gahhh, i guess that makes sense, this was the case in any bakery shop in chinatown. i saw some dim sum rice crepe rolls with shrimp and i love that stuff so i got excited, thought it was worth the effort to try to find an atm around. hiked up a couple blocks to a bank of america, got cash and came back to wait in line. only to find the dim sum rice crepe is $4.50, 4 flipping 50??? that is more than fresh dim sum at a restaurant. but by this point i had gone too far to not get it so i got 2. also ordered 2 lotus cakes and red bean paste cakes and an egg custard roll. While i compliment on the worker here, maybe my compliment was extended a little too in advance. she had given me 4 red bean paste cakes instead of 2 lotus and 2 red beans. so i ended up red bean caking it up. the red bean cakes were not good, at all. egg custard roll was pretty good but honestly, no place ever screws that up. the cheong fun or shrimp rice crepes were good, but still not worth that much. oh they gave you soy sauce for that stuff too. Basically if you come here before 3PM, you can ask them to make more of their ready to bag for to go dim sum. And yes, you can come here and there are 3 tables, you can definitely order dim sum here if you want, very limited menu though,i'd say about 20 items all together. has your congee, rice crepes, turnip cakes, chicken feet etc. I am assuming the dim sum on the Chinese only dim sum menu displayed by the stove is much smaller portion than the pre-packaged dim sum, because rice crepe on the chinese only dim sum menu was supposed to be $2.50 and they charge $4.50 for the pre-packaged ones. let me point out that the pictures posted here is deceiving, because when i was there on a sunday afternoon, they did not have nearly as many options. if you are able to bust chinese with the workers, usually they are not rude and treat you a bit nicer, while i can bust decent chinese, or cantonese for that matter, i can't really read the signs of the pastries well, so that is no help.

45.description: This is where I usually get my favorite bakery. Butterfly Cookie, walnut red bean paste, sponge cake..... It's so cheap & the taste is even better.

33.description: I'm still eating my way around the new neighborhood.  I stumbled into this place while waiting for my order from the place next door.  I've been back a few times, especially when I need cheap eats.  My favorite item, the steamed pork buns, are only about a buck.  Good news, they're big; bad news, there's not enough filling for the amount of bread.  Doesn't matter, I'll still be back when I have a couple of bucks.

43.description: When we lived in Rogers Park, I would frequent this bakery for all my Chinese bakery cravings, especially their char siu bao. Since moving out to the burbs, I have made special trips into Uptown for groceries and stop by Chiu Quon just to purchase a dozen of these baos at a time among other favorite baked goods. They make solid traditional goods like egg tarts, red bean filled fried sesame balls, sponge cake, etc. However, yesterday I was extremely disappointed because they pulled a bait and switch when it came to my order of char siu bao. I am certain I was crystal clear in ordering a dozen char siu bao... and the lady there kept asking me if I wanted the ones with egg in it to which I replied NO I Do NOT WANT EGG - three times. If they didn't have any left, I would be fine had she told me that. I should have been skeptical when she rang me up and charged me about $7 for 6 baos (more than I was accustomed to). When I ate one today I discovered that she had sold me, yup, a dozen baos adulterated with egg and Chinese sausage. My impression is that she must have really wanted to get rid of them because maybe people weren't buying them (they just aren't as good as regular char siu baos) and thought she could pass em off on me... 'cause what am I going to do? Drive an hour back to argue? I've had a couple of disappointments in my last few visits there as it seems they have gone down in their selection of my favorites. It's not like I expect awesome customer service from a Chinese bakery... 'cause that's not a realistic expectation. I do, however, expect to order something and if told that they have it available that they actually sell me what I asked for. This last visit disappointed me enough to actually post this review.Not going to make the trip to Uptown for Chiu Quon anymore. I think I'll stick to the downtown one... I do better there and they seem more with it given they have considerably more competition in that 'hood from St. Anna's and others.

2.description: Been frequenting chiu con bakeries since I was a little girl. The baked goods are great and get an a1 for taste.I would recommend getting egg tarts, sponge cake bread, sesame balls or a ham and egg bun :)cons: I think it could be cleaner, same for the other location

18.description: Their ish is my jam. I've been going to this bakery since I was a kid. The same lady has worked there ever since. I absolutely love all of their items. Be aggressive when ordering! Also it's cash only! Be sure to get their early, especially on weekends since they sell out fast. You will encounter lines on weekends. Enjoy a hot asian bun today :)

41.description: Sesame balls and BBQ pork buns are super good and affordable. One of each is $1.85! Remember to bring cash!

52.description: Went on a Sunday morning. There's a line, nearly out the door and some customers aren't super respectful of the line. Place is cash only. Prices are great. They have sweets and buns with different types of filling in them (pork, egg, shrimp, etc). Its a great local authentic place to get a quick filling bite. And its right off the Argyle stop! Yey!

50.description: Chiu Quon carries a broad range of Chinese pastries, but I come here specifically for the steamed buns and bread. While their baked pastries are fine, I prefer the same baked pastries from La PatisserieP (located down the street) because they have a higher filling-to-bread ratio. La PatisserieP also carries more cakes, Swiss rolls, and other such Western-ish pastries.Bring cash and be prepared to wait in line.

4.description: Chiu Quon Bakery has all of my favorite China Town baked goods for the same or similar prices. I don't know the names of all of them.The interior is grody (just like the bakeries in China Town). I don't know if they have the best sanitation practices in place. For example, they might go from touching cash to touching food. The meat buns aren't refrigerated.They're cash only (which is different from the bakeries in China Town). Once I asked for four siomai and ended up with four orders (16 total).

6.description: Cash only. Friendly service, especially for Asians. Sweet treats I swoon over: Egg Tarts, Steamed Rice Cake and Coconut TartsTheir egg tarts have flakiest crust in town, especially the bigger ones (they have small tarts for $0.55 each and large tarts for $1.10 each). I've also never found rice cakes as moist and tender as this place. They sell hefty tray for $2.Savory Goodness: Ham and Egg Buns, Roast Pork Buns, Egg and Veggie Stir-Fry Concoction (contains small amount of shrimp and ham) that is served out of a giant wok that sits atop the glass counter all day. Don't forget: cash only.

22.description: Their ish is my jam. I've been going to this bakery since I was a kid. The same lady has worked there ever since. I absolutely love all of their items. Be aggressive when ordering! Also it's cash only! Be sure to get their early, especially on weekends since they sell out fast. You will encounter lines on weekends. Enjoy a hot asian bun today :)

15.description: Love this bakery! It is owned by Hiananese Chinese so I might be a little partial. They also have a bakery in the old part of Chinatown and both seem to be doing very well. The workers are very friendly and helpful. Everyone speaks English very well, so it is very easy to place your order or ask questions about certain items. Because they have such good business, most of their items look like it is freshly made each day.Favorites include:-Sesame balls (fried gluttonous rice balls filled with red bean)-Char kway tiao/Youtiao (fried Chinese crullers)-Lotus bean cake with an egg yoke

57.description: Seriously, what's with all the 4 star reviews? I don't normally write Yelp reviews, but I could not let this injustice stand. These are ridiculously good pastries for ridiculously inexpensive prices - if you can name a better Asian bakery, I'd like to know where it is. I graduated college and left Chicago a couple years ago, and this place was on my list of must-visits when I came back for homecoming. Amazingly, their prices don't seem to have gone up at all since I left, or really any time in the last 5+ years. Why pay $5 for a gourmet cupcake (and don't get me wrong, I like cupcakes as much as the next girl) when you can come here and get a big box of stuff for less than that?Their sponge cakes (the ones baked into the paper wrappers) are the best anywhere - I've searched high and low (LA, SF, Seattle..) and nothing else even comes close. They are consistently light, fluffy, spongy, and not too sweet. Like eating a really delicious cloud. And have I mentioned they're ridiculously cheap? I got an extra 3 of these for the road, but I would have bought out the entire stock if I could. I would sell my firstborn child to get my hands on their sponge cake recipe, it's THAT good.The red bean-filled sesame balls are also really tasty, especially when you get them hot - not overly greasy. Egg tarts are solid too.If there are any downsides to this place, it's the fact that it's cash only. Totally worth it, though. Also, if you go late in the afternoon on a weekend, they can sell out of some items.I miss you, Chiu Quon. Please open up a branch on the West Coast?

20.description: Cash only! I love that most times there not sold out in the late afternoon when I get there.  Sometimes it's a slight struggle with language but hey it all works out in the end.

36.description: I love this place! It's a childhood favorite and even till now. Keep doing a great job guys! :)

14.description: Love this bakery. The food is really cheap but it's absolutely delicious. The place is Vietnamese owned and if you're not Viet you might have a hard time communicating with the store workers, but it works out because you can just point at what you want through the glass screen. The place is also cash only so beware. I always stop by here when I go to argyle to grab pho

12.description: The best Vietnamese sandwich (banh mi) in Chicago.

7.description: The lemongrass chicken banh mi was surprisingly good.  I get bored of chicken sometimes, but it was very nicely marinated and fresh tasting.  The Chinese bbq pork banh mi was also good but I suppose right on par with Ba Le and Tank.  That goes for the bread as well - a good balance of crispiness and fluffy chewiness!We also ordered a mango-pineapple blend to wash down the sandwiches, which I really enjoyed.  I admit there might've been a little bias since we went to Joy Yee ToGo the night before and ordered the same thing - only to get a very mediocre version there.  In comparison this was way, way more satisfying.  Will return!EDIT:  Tried to return.  They close at 6pm during the week, and 7pm on the weekends!  So early...so much for stopping by for a quick banh mi dinner after work :(

19.description: #1 Nhu Lan Banh Mi is the bomb

1.description: I noticed this place opened in a little strip mall on Lawrence & Sheridan not that long ago and I've wanted to try ever since. The opportunity never knocked for myself and Nhu Lan to meet as I have either already eaten or had plans to eat while passing.Yesterday I went to pick up my dry cleaning in that same strip mall and was not thrilled by anything in my freezer or fridge. I saw Nhu Lan as its really the only place within the strip mall that has a lit up sign and thought perfect timing. I walked in and noticed the place was well lit with cooked meat behind glass and a refrigerate area with cold sandwiches, shakes and soft drinks. The different options are on the wall and the grilled pork banh mi sandwich caught my eye. I got it to go and it probably took 5 mins to make it from the kitchen to me. I got home and was surprised how big it was...I had to cut it in half. Very good sandwich for $4 and some change. This place is within walking distance from me so I have no excuse to go here for more deliciousness.

2.description: Whenever we go out for a picnic or just fast food, we always call nhu lan for their bahn mis. Recently, however, we have even tried Nhu Lan's shrimp crepes, spring rolls, and pho. They were all very good. As for bahn mi's, the usuals are the pork belly and the nhu lan special. I like the stickers that are put onto our sandwiches with actual labels rather than the normal marker marks on the paper. The small things I get happiness from is funny to most.  The French baguette of Nhu Lan's bahn mis are texturally perfect, nice and soft inside, and a little crunch on the outside. I also think their bread is bigger than most bahn mis but that could just be my imagination. They have a deal like most Vietnmese restaurants where if you buy 5, you get one free. This gets me every time,  so what I usually ask them to do is put the condiments on the side for the ones I'll eat later on in the day or the week. I usually head up my sandwich in the oven the next day for about 5-7 minutes for yummy deviousness.   Who says you have to go to Argyle for great Vietnamese food.  Go to Nhu Lan where there's also a parking lot!! Major plus!!

9.description: I love this place and am super glad its opened up another one!! I love this place and would pick it over Ba Le anytime!Easy to find in the new market centerSpring rolls are on steroidsThe lemongrass chicken banh mi is a great choice if you don't eat beef or pork like me!They have about 19 different types of banh mis, and over 10 different types of vietnamese dessert drinks. I had the 3 color drink and it was tasty, you can also request to add ice with your drink.Their food is reasonably priced and filling! Also they have super dope specials, buy 5 banh mis, get one free, buy 5 egg rolls get one free!

6.description: Hidden Gem Alert:  You would have no idea this place was here unless you lived in the neighborhood and happened to stumble upon it or had it recommended like I did.  Definitely worth the stop.  I've been twice now in the past week and this place is legit.  The Bun Bao, the roasted pork and even the fruit smoothies.  Don't let the strip mall that surrounds this place discourage you.  Make a pit stop.

18.description: Cheap, delicious, friendly. I literally go here several times a week. Try the lemongrass tofu, you won't believe it's not meat. Also, extra pâté on a Banh Mi is never a bad decision.

10.description: This place is the real deal. I get the lemongrass tofu sandwich and it honestly tastes better than some bahn mi I ate in Ho Chi Minh city. The tofu is super flavorful and has the texture of meat (I am not even vegetarian.) the place is tiny but I usually eat at their small tables. Also the women who work there are really nice, and you know it's good when the majority of the customers who walk in the door are vietnamese :)

13.description: i think i may have tried a bun bao at every bakery in this 1 mile radius.  i am a bun bao addict and this place is one of my favorites.  they have both a traditional bun bao with ground pork and a xa xiu pork version.  the bun baos are a bit more expensive than the other bakeries but still suffices as a very cheap mini meal/snack. the dough to filling ratio is good and the dough is fluffy and soft with a bit of sweetness.  meat is well flavored. they will also heat it up for you if ask.  they also have fresh banh chung and banh tet and other tet (Vietnamese new years) goodies right now

16.description: I am beyond thrilled that my favorite Ban Mi just moved in closer to home. Will be here  all the time.

17.description: So thrilled they have opened a location in Uptown! The best bahn mi in the city, in my opinion, with four vegetarian options and delicious bubble tea. Friendly service and a truly great addition to the neighborhood. Oh, and FREE PARKING!

15.description: Glad to be the 1st review on this location...  Yay! Omg, their sandwiches are AWESOME!!! We got #1 - Nhu lan Special and #3 - Lemongrass Chicken last time.... They were both unbelievable... Definitely will be back soon :)

0.description: We stumbled upon this place before a concert at the Aragon Ballroom. They don't seem to have a wide selection, but they have amazing bahn mi sandwiches and pho here. The pho is nice and hot, especially good when it's cold out. I'd definitely eat here again. It didn't seem like they have a public restroom, but they have a huge strip mall parking lot. They have food to go already ready. It's wheelchair accessible.

5.description: Fantastic! I can't believe I've been passing by this spot. I see that I'm missing out on the biggest banh mi sandwich that I've had in the city. I had to have an appetizer as I was starving and this was a late lunch for me, so the pork egg roll really hit the spot. The star is truly the sandwich and of course I had to get the special because I want everything. Ingredients were fresh, and I was so tempted to take other packaged items home. The prices are very reasonable, and a great value for your money. Staff is polite and quick. I will certainly come back here.

11.description: Great banh mi sandwiches and Pho. Takeout preferred as there's only a couple of small tables. Friendly staff.

8.description: Great warm, flakey bread; chicken had tons of flavor and was juicy, too. Great value; Will be back

3.description: Their lemongrass tofu and ginger tofu banh mi are way better than their competition's vegan options, larger, and cheaper. You won't recognize the tofu as tofu, either, it's pretty good as fake meat goes.Sadly there was a fire! Hopefully they'll be back, but they've been closed since mid/late December. There is another Nhu Lan a couple miles west on Lawrence if you need your fix, but afaik they don't deliver. :(

14.description: Love the place, it's new to this part of Uptown but in my opinion quickly becoming a favorite!! Their sandwiches are tasty, spring rolls are awesome and I'm looking forwarding to trying the PHO!

4.description: To me, Nhu Lan and Ba Le are the top two banh mi bakeries in Chicago.  I like both of them for different reasons, but this new location really impressed me!  The lemongrass chicken was marinated in a unique sauce and super flavorful.  The Chinese roasted pork was also good, but the sweet bbq flavor is more commonplace. The French bread they came in tasted fresh out of the oven.  From the look of it, you'll wonder how you can bite into something so monstrous, but your mouth will press down on warm, soft fluffy bread with just the right amount of chewy crust.  Pickled vegetables, carrots, and cucumbers made me feel like less of a carnivore.  My only disappointment was that the mango pineapple smoothie tasted artificial, but my boyfriend was a fan so to each their own.  There are only 3 tiny tables that seat 2 and no restrooms; take-out may be more comfortable, but we happily devoured the sandwiches in record time.

58.description: Took a walk around after enjoying some pho at Tank Noodle restaurant and found this bakery.Decided to go in here to get some dessert and to get away from the freezing cold weather while walking around.  This was a EuroAsian bakery.  Only tried a few things since we were still full from the pho.  Tried the Red bean paste bun and it was out of this world! Melted in my mouth like butter.  Also tried the butterfly cookies and it was also very delicious.  I want to go back to Chicago. =(      I'm a fan fan fan fan. ^_^

56.description: Love this place, their bakery, the people.Admittedly, my husband and I have frequent flyer status here. Last night my husband stops and calls me from there. He is taking a little longer than expected because the ladies (in the true sense of the word) behind the counter know I like the almond chocolate croissants and they are BAKING ME UP A COUPLE. Um,top that.

29.description: Great little bakery with savory and sweet goods.

42.description: I've had La Patisserie P on my bookmarks for the better part of a year now, and every year it's one (well, really only) of my resolutions to try and get to as many bookmarked places as possible. Obviously I don't set very lofty resolutions for myself, but I'm nothing if not realistic.Anyway, I'd read somewhere (and honestly it's been so long that I don't recall where) that LPP had one of the best chocolate croissants in the city. I had to do my due diligence to see if this was true, especially since the closest bakery to my house does not sell their croissants individually (see La Boulangerie review). LPP is far enough away that I couldn't make it a super-regular stop for croissants, but if it proved to be worthy, I could definitely make the effort.I stopped in in the late afternoon and it suddenly occurred to me that they could very well be out of croissants (as they're more of a breakfast pastry). Thankfully they still had some, but they also had many other delicious looking pastries, as well as other delights like bbq pork buns. Despite its French name, La Patisserie P offers Asian items as well (both savory and sweet). Everything looked so elegant and well-crafted.In addition to two chocolate croissants, I also purchased an adorable mini strawberry mousse cake. The three items totaled about $8, which I found to be very reasonably priced.I thought the croissants were only okay, but to be fair, I did purchase them later in the day so perhaps they were baked that morning, and I also did not eat them until the following morning. The chocolate inside was a long piece of chocolate that was not really baked in, so it was hard. I much prefer when it's soft and melted inside. I ended up heating it up for a minute but that only rendered the pastry tough.I did love the strawberry mousse cake though, which was pleasantly tart and sweet and tasted like fresh strawberries. The cake part was spongy and moist and held up well to the mousse. I would definitely go back just for this.

23.description: Awesome food! Very friendly staff. I love the Chinese sausage Siao Pao (Show Pow).

47.description: I highly recommend La Patisserie P for anything pastry related (they are a bakery after all), but would steer away from most of their beverages.There are a handful of Vietnamese bakeries on Argyle Street in this stretch known as Little Saigon, but none are even on the same playing field as La Patisserie P.  They have married French and Vietnamese baking so splendidly to create an assortment of baked goods that are eye candy as well as mouth candy.  They actually have a number of intriguing savory baked goods, so you could plausibly come here for an entire meal.Though they have items such as bubble tea and smoothies on their menu, I would steer clear.  My last time in I ordered a bubble tea and had the luxury of watching it be made from scratch.  Kudos for that... I think it's great when drinks are not made from mixes.  Yet their special black tea was (drumroll please) a standard Lipton tea bag with half and half.  In the end, just not terribly impressive.But don't let that deter you from coming in.  La Patisserie P is truly spectacular for what they do well: pastries.  So go eat some pastries.

8.description: I'd advise anyone to stay away from this place because they are not an honest business.  They CONSTANTLY change their prices without notification and DO NOT display their prices on their items.  I've also been overcharged on several occasions.  Their stuff is just OK, nothing special.  Not worth the premium they charge on their items which is slightly higher than a typical Cantonese bakery.  But most importantly, they're not transparent about their pricing which is unacceptable.

31.description: I feel so lucky to have this place just a few blocks from my apartment. It's one of the things that makes living in Uptown such a pleasure. I feel sorry for those who live in more high end, hip neighborhoods in Chicago like Wicker Park, Logan Square, the Loop or LIncoln Square because they just don't know what they are missing! I love the BBQ pork buns here, but especially the curry chicken buns!. Once a year they offer a specialty dried spiced pork pastry which is to die for (its like the best foccaccia you have ever had!). The service is always very friendly and prompt, the food amazing. I can't imagine a better food experience than Patisserie P!

34.description: Wow, what a find. Actually, how did I not find this place until now? Small place full of tasty baked goods, I think I found my go-to place for a very tasty Vietnamese iced coffee and custard bun. The Shui Mai bun was a first for me, but was fresh out of the oven and super delicious. Im a fan.

16.description: Why, oh why, did I have to discover this place? This is so bad. It's on my way to the redline and the sweet lady who either owns it or runs it makes some really amazing Vietnamese iced coffee. While I didn't try any of the goodies, they looked delicious so it's going to be quite a challenge to fight the urge on my morning walks. Grrrr.

13.description: The customer service provided at this cozy little cafe was a big win. I speak both Mandarin and Tagalog (Filipino) in equal fluency so I was intrigued as a first time customer to find that all the items had both Mandarin and Tagalog written out. It dawned on me that this was a Chinese/Filipino bakery. I want to point out that this place has the BEST Putong Puti (Filipino steamed white rice cake also eaten in other SE Asias nations and parts of southern China) on Argyle. I've bought  Puto from Unimart ( A Filipino Oriental Food Chain), Assi Market, Super H, various markets on Argyle and the surrounding area and nothing  as moist and pleasantly chewy as the Puto at La Patisserie P.  Those heavenly morsels of yummylicious happiness are to die for. I also bought a giant Ensaymada (Filipino Puff pastry) which was pleasant but it did not wow me. I'd definitely buy it again and eat it with a nice hot cup of coffee or tea. Although, I wish they topped it with traditional Filipino cheese since that's  what Ensymada is usually supposed to be crowned with. We bought Hopia Ube/Taro (Hopiang Ube) which is an everyday pastry in the Philippines. This needs to be corrected - Ube, aka purple yam, is not the same thing as Taro.  I would have to say the Hopia Ube/Taro is only Hopia Taro. Hopia Ube has a very dark purple filling. Ube, aka purple yam, is much sweeter, milkier and richer than most yams. It sometimes tastes like cookies and cream in its natural form. OVERALL - Amazing experience. My friends and I will continue to be loyal customers to this bakery.

11.description: I'm sorry to find out about this place after living in the hood for 6 months! Friendly, gracious women at the counter are always able to make a suggestion of what to try (so far nothing has been even close to mediocre) I would have never noticed the shop unless a friend had pointed it out and recommended the caramel pecan tart. Mmmmmmm

39.description: Oh  BBQ pork buns. You sneaky little buggers. I am going to buy twelve of you next time I go in there!Bun heaven, ladies and gentlemen, and no I'm not talking about David Beckham. (Badum-CHH!) This shop is for real a hidden gem, and while I want you all to go there, I don't want anyone to eat all the pork buns. Or the custard buns- those are amazing too. And the prices are crazy! I got five items for around $7. In all honesty, I'm going to have to branch out next time I go in and order something other than buns and eclairs- even though I don't want to. But the chef has a really impressive resume (think Four Seasons & Sofitel along with classical training from Master Pastry Chefs in Hong Kong), and I know people who have trained under him, so I just assume that the rest of it has to be out of this world as well. But I'm still getting the pork buns.

37.description: As an update:  "I want to move to this neighborhood just so I can live near this bakery."I do actually now live in this neighborhood, and La Patisserie P was one of the reasons I picked it!I still love my cream horns, and Chocolate Obsession (oh yeah.)A quick tip, however: avoid the savory buns. I find gristle in them a little too often. Go to nearby Chiu Quon for your sticky bun needs.

0.description: The freshest, most delicious custard bao on Argyle. Start carrying Mr. Brown's canned coffee and sweet top red-bean buns, and Chi Quon would be a thing of the past!Great smoothies with tapioca pearls. The red bean smoothie is also a thing of beauty. I love their biscotti as well.

38.description: La Patisserie P is a family-run bakery. There is a wide selection of buns and pastries. For $3.95 each, we had a piece of tiramisu cheesecake and chocolate ganache cake. For $2.95 each, we had a piece of mango cheesecake, caramel pecan tart, lemon meringue tart, and mocha napoleon. In total, our order was approximately $22.   The cake were on par. They were small and not heavily-sweetened. The mocha napoleon was flakey and had many layers. It was very bland although it had a sweet mocha aroma. The lemon meringue tart was not particularly sour. The flavors had a lighter edge. The caramel pecan tart was the highlight of the batch. It wasn't overly sweet but it was very rich. Would definitely return for this caramel pecan tart!

51.description: Their food may be good but the rude service is a deal-breaker.  Extremely unhelpful staff will do the bare minimum.  I will never go there again.I tried to work with them for a large order and was told rudely that the chef was out of town.  When I asked when he (or she?) would return, I was told they didn't know.  Maybe a month.Which is okay, you know, since everyone needs some time away.But the kicker is when I asked if there was someone else, anyone else, I could talk to, the woman simply said "No.  Nobody can help you."Alrighty then.  They lost a customer.

27.description: My mom's bday and she wants dinner in the city?  Considering she lives in the burbs and has never enjoyed the drive into the city, this was a surprise and unheard of.We go ahead and lock in the restaurant, and decide we definitely need to get her a cake of some sort, seeing that it's one of the more important birthday!  (You know, 1st, 18th, 21st, 30th, 45th, 50th, 65th, etc.)Trusty yelp leads me to La Patisserie!  While their online presence/website really is no help at all with regards to options/choices, the lady on the phone was plenty friendly and took the time to go through the different cake varieties.  Mango/passion fruit mousse chocolate cake.  Yup.  Done and done.  The chocolate layers were soft and lightly flavored, which was a perfect compliment to the smooth and fragrant flavors of mango and passion fruit mousse that served as thick top layer over the cake.  Verdict:  Mom loved the red bean sesame balls (her favorite dessert) which I tricked her into believing was her cake substitute.  She liked the actual cake even more!  Win win.Bonus:  It's a Chinese/Filipino bakery with French technique, so they were able to write "Happy Birthday Mom" in Chinese for us... and some of those Filipino snacks looked pretty divine.  Perhaps the wife and I need to make our way back for some snacks...

32.description: I highly recommend this place for cakes!  Peter did an amazing job with our engagement cake!  We had three flavors: red velvet, mango, and hazelnut.  Everyone at the party was raving about how delicious the cake was.

54.description: THE CROISSANTS AND FREAKING AMAZING!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!They're light, butter, flaky, and just so delicious!! The best I've ever had!! I always buy a box of them before I head down to Champaign for school.Their red bean paste buns and sweet top buns are also super tasty. And cheap! Whoo! There are many other traditional Chinese buns there too, as well as a wide assortment of European pastries and sweets. I haven't tried them all yet, but I plan to! Yum yum!The kids of the owner are so sweet too! They're school age and on weekends and during winter/summer breaks, they help out in the kitchen! Good kids, love 'em!GO!!!!!!!!!

48.description: this place is amazing. i go in here a couple times a month and you wouldn't believe the amount of goodies you can get for $10! the savory and sweet buns are all delicious and only $1 a piece. the sesame balls are just the right amount of crispy and chewy. the bao's are fresh and full of flavor. the cakes are available in tons of different flavors and all taste great. but last weekend i got this creme puff thing that was off the charts good. i'm bound to put a few pounds on now that i know about those. i've never had a bad dish yet. this has got to be one of my favorite bakeries in the entire city. thrilled, but miserable that it's so close to home. i always need more time in the gym because of it.

44.description: Very cool place with delicious butter pastries, though I suspect they're not using full butter in most of these recipes.  While they're very tasty, they don't taste quite like full butter croissants and cookies like I've had in French bakeries.  Regardless, textures and tastes are nice, the variety of hot savory Asian buns and French sweets is really nice.  Go in for Breakfast treats and pick up buns for lunch later at the same time.  Fair prices and friendly service, easy street parking, too.   The chocolate almond croissants are sooooo good.  Grab two--one for now, one for later.    Four of these and six butterfly butter cookies were $15, so a cheap, inexpensive way to make someone's day so much sweeter in Uptown.

24.description: Stopped in for some treats after a nice lunch, the fruit tart was flavorless, Red velvet cookie was really dry and tasted burnt.  But the cookies that were on sale were AWESOME!!  They were small sugar cookies that were absolutely marvelous, well so in for some other pastries, the hot dog in a bun looked interesting :)

7.description: Growing up in a Chinese family, traditional pastries were staples in our diet. You would think that it's hard to wow me with them.  Yet, LaPastisserie P managed to do that with their pineapple buns and sponge cakes!  Imagine fluffy pillows of bread topped with a thin crumbly, sweet shell AND if you're lucky enough to get them warm, you'll be in for a heavenly treat!  They are only available on the weekends so plan accordingly.  Their sponge cakes are so airy and light with the perfect mild sweetness.Besides these two items, their French pastries set them aside from the standard Chinese bakery.  I have not ventured into trying everything as I enjoy these two so much, although the other items I've tried (egg tarts, bbq pork, ham and egg and coconut buns, etc.) are good as well - albeit pretty standard.Edit: I ordered a two layer cake for a special event, and the owner made an amazing mango mousse/coconut sponge cake that everyone loved.  It ran $5 per slice.

49.description: Found this place as I was on my way to dinner at Sun Wah. I had been craving Asian sweets, so I went a little crazy when I got here. I got egg tarts, cocktail buns, taro buns, coconut buns, almond cookies, sesame balls... The list goes on. Of the things I've tried so far, I can say that I am pleasantly surprised by the flavor and authenticity of the pastries. The egg tarts have a flaky crust and a moist custard, but I wish they were a little sweeter. The sesame balls are nice and chewy. The inside of the cocktail bun is delicious, but the bread is a little stale. Still, for the price ($12 for a HUGE box of pastries) this place can't be beat!Will try their French pastries and savory items next time.

40.description: La Patisserie P is a consistently delicious north side Asian bakery.  The French(?) pastries are also good, but why would you buy those when the red bean paste balls are 1000000x more delicious than any tart ever made (and also much cheaper)?  I've really enjoyed all the desserts I've had here (red bean paste balls, hopia red bean bun, and melon roll or something like that).  Additionally, their savory buns are ALSO delicious - the barbecue pork and curry buns are delicious.  Bubble tea is a plus too.

53.description: This place is awesome!  Came here to get some Pork Bao and left with a bag of tasty treats.  Croissants were great (as Karen L. pointed out).  BTW, I don't know who Karen L is but I agree with her review.  I will definitely come back over and over again.

30.description: This amazing place carries both Chinese bakery goods and French pastries.  I just finished my Valencia and am still licking the fork.  The almond chocolate croissant is a must try and it sells out fast!  You can tell the owner is very passionate about his products.  Walking into this place is like walking into a Tiffany's - imagine how hard it is to choose between mango mousse cheesecake, creme burlee and New York cheesecake when they are right next to each other!

46.description: ordered a chocolate croissant to go and it was crispy and flaky.

1.description: I got the issue with the extra charges fixed, so I'm updating my review.They have delicious pastries, my favorite being the taro ube buns. Sponge cakes are on the larger side, so they are more pricy.The prices are not listed, and this place is definitely more expensive than the other bakeries in the area.I would just ask for the price of every item in advance, and pay with cash.Other than that, it's a decent place to get good tasting Chinese baked goods. I still have yet to try the French pastries.

55.description: I've been coming to this place before it was even known as La Patisserie (it's been so long, I forgot its original name). I used to love come to this place as a kid and getting little desserts and ham and cheese buns - - soooo good. Unfortunately, I stopped in with my mom and boyfriend to pick up some almond cookies and pandesal (Filipino sweet bread) this past Monday and my mom pointed out that they now have ensyamadas (Filipino pastry topped with sugar, butter, and cheese) and as I got really excited to purchase one, I noticed something black and moving on the glass... Yep, it was a cockroach about the size of a pinky nail INSIDE the glass case. We told the cashier, who said "Oh, it happens when we open the glass door." Uh, that's not an explanation - that was garbage. Then they would move the trays around to try and find it, but didn't actually remove the food from the case... Needless to say, we did not purchase the ensyamada as they are not individually wrapped, nor were the other items inside this particular case. My mom still purchased puto (Filipino moist rice cake) since it was wrapped on top of the case and I purchased two almond cookies, mainly because I kept telling myself it was in the other case. I've seen cockroaches and had them living in my childhood apartment, I understand that it's an urban city so it's bound to happen. But I can't get the image out of my head that there is a possible problem of the food getting walked all over by a roach that came from who knows where.I'm really disappointed by this because I really did like the place, but now I can't shake how gross it could possibly be.

9.description: I'm writing this review back to back with my review of Chiu Quon, which is another Chinese bakery on Argyle - I come to Patisserie P specifically for their sweet top bun (bo lo bao, or pineapple bun).  It's different!  The bread inside is really soft and fluffy, and the cookie crust on top is guaranteed to make a sugary mess when you bite into it, as it should be.  They also have corned beef buns and curry buns, the former of which Chiu Quon just doesn't have.  They also have a decent selection of Western/European style baked goods which you might not find a lot of on Argyle, but I haven't tried them yet.One thing that bothers me a little about this place is that they usually try to upsell me - they have a deal for 5 or 6 buns for a discounted price, but the discount isn't that substantial.

26.description: Delicious!  Had 2 tarts, caramel/walnut and pecan.   Omg!!  Cant wait to get more!

25.description: Why, oh why, did I have to discover this place? This is so bad. It's on my way to the redline and the sweet lady who either owns it or runs it makes some really amazing Vietnamese iced coffee. While I didn't try any of the goodies, they looked delicious so it's going to be quite a challenge to fight the urge on my morning walks. Grrrr.

12.description: Ordered two cakes over the phone for my event and they were knowledgeable and helpful especially when I requested they take care of the design because I trusted them. The fruit cakes turned out beautiful and delicious! Can't wait till my next event!

59.description: I cannot accurately express how thrilled I am to have found this place, a mere mile from my apartment, thanks to other Yelpers. My 10-year-long search for a great croissant in this city has ended! Flaky, light, just sweet enough AND crusty -- perfection. I can't speak for the savory buns everyone raves about (I'm a vegetarian), but the green bean paste bun I had was outstanding. My friend got almond cookies and said they were delicious, too.They have a unique mix of European-style and popular Asian bakery items. It doesn't get much more convenient or delicious than this. Plus, the front-of-store people are as nice as can be.The other great thing about coming here was that it introduced me to an amazing area of my neighborhood I had no idea existed. Whether you call it "Little Saigon" or the "New Chinatown" -- what an amazing few blocks.I'm definitely coming back to try some of their breads and other sweets!

21.description: This is my neighborhood bakery and I love everything about it. The pastries are not only delicious, but beautiful. Everything is reasonably priced and I rarely make it out of the store with fewer than 3 treats.

17.description: With Chiu Quon down the street, one might wonder why they should step into this bakery. Well, if you are interested in the following:1. *baked* Chinese pastries with more filling and or2. a larger choice of Western pastriesthen you should stop by and peruse the selection. However, if you're looking for *steamed* buns or bread, then you should go to Chiu Quon because La PatisserieP doesn't have them. La PatisserieP is slightly more expensive than Chiu Quon, and by that I mean 5-10 cents more per baked good, but it's worth the greater amount of filling in their pastries. Plus, credit cards are accepted here.If anyone was wondering, yes you can freeze Chinese pastries (baked or steamed), so I make a point of stocking up when I stop by. Also, if you're driving to this area, park on Broadway or Sheridan because parking on Argyle is a nearly impossible task.

10.description: Their creme brûlée is bomb. They light it up after you buy it. Their French horn is flaky, semi-sweet and light. Their Japanese cheesecake tasted like a tart angel cake. Their mango cheesecake had a light mango layer with a semi-sweet tart cheesecake. The ladies that work there are so nice. I would've given the place a 4 stars but the service was worth changing it to a 5 star.

5.description: I like chiu quon and I am always impressed by the sheer variety they offered but I like Pattiserie because the bakers were so nice and friendly. The lady at the front gave me recommendations and she talked to me about college, and I was so touched by her ingenuity and kindness. The baked goods seem to have love and care put into them. They offered swiss rolls, buns, and a lot of other frenchy goods. I like the sweet bean bun and the taro swiss roll. I definitely am coming back ! Very affordable and yummy.7 dollar credit card limit.

3.description: LaPatisserie P is a tiny little bakery right off of the Argyle red line stop that produces all sorts of fresh Asian and French sweets and confections everyday of the week.  From croissants to filled buns to cookies, swiss rolls, and breads, they've got it all and in a ton of different flavors!  I feel like the women behind the counter are maybe a little bit pushy to get you to purchase all of their delicious creations, but honestly they do give off a really nice vibe.In the times that I've gone here, I can definitely say that it's in your best interest to stick to the Asian baked goods before anything else.  The French entremets and miniature cakes and tarts look good, but flavor-wise I felt they kind of fell flat.  Nothing was pronounced and every flavor was subdued.  Even the chocolate in the opera cake was just kind of boring and somehow bland.  Certainly not something I'd order again.But their Asian confections on the other hand are out of this world!  I had a fresh custard bun right out of the oven and the dough was so light, soft, and milky, and the filling was just that wonderful warm egg-based cream you find in Asian egg tarts.  One alone is probably perfect for a lunch or a midday snack, and believe me - it was super filling and scrumptious!   Other than that, I have to give them HUGE props for their sesame red bean paste-filled mochi ball.  It's a common Asian treat, but my God is their version good.  Perfectly sticky soft mochi encased in toasted umami-filled sesame seeds filled with a smooth red bean paste.  Just what the doctor ordered any day of the week!! If I could only order one thing from here ever again, it would absolutely be that.So bottom line is that this is a great place to go if you enjoy Asian baked goods.  If it's not your thing, give them a try anyway - you might find out you like them after all, because these ladies have got it!

35.description: With Chiu Quon down the street, one might wonder why they should step into this bakery. Well, if you are interested in the following:1. *baked* Chinese pastries with more filling and or2. a larger choice of Western pastriesthen you should stop by and peruse the selection. However, if you're looking for *steamed* buns or bread, then you should go to Chiu Quon because La PatisserieP doesn't have them. La PatisserieP is slightly more expensive than Chiu Quon, and by that I mean 5-10 cents more per baked good, but it's worth the greater amount of filling in their pastries. Plus, credit cards are accepted here.If anyone was wondering, yes you can freeze Chinese pastries (baked or steamed), so I make a point of stocking up when I stop by. Also, if you're driving to this area, park on Broadway or Sheridan because parking on Argyle is a nearly impossible task.

19.description: A great find in Lincoln Park. The main reason I go is the creme horns, they're HUGE. The different rolls with meats are good as well, although they all kind of taste the same. The staff is friendly & helpful. You must try the creme horns!

28.description: A great find in Lincoln Park. The main reason I go is the creme horns, they're HUGE. The different rolls with meats are good as well, although they all kind of taste the same. The staff is friendly & helpful. You must try the creme horns!

45.description: I generally have good experiences with the croissants at Patisserie P, but today was different.   I got there a few minutes early, and although the door was unlocked, I was told I couldn't enter.  After standing out on Argyle for 8 awkward minutes, I went back in and ordered 2 almond croissants.  I was told to wait.  Evidently, this waiting time was so they could burn a couple croissants and do a cover-up job with powdered sugar.  For $6.42, I deserve better.  I like to go there for impulsive special morning breakfasts, but the whole idea is tainted now.

33.description: La PatisserieP is a great place, dangerously located between me and the el every morning. Everything I've had has been fantastic and beautifully inexpensive. The croissants are perfectly buttery and flaky. Go for the almond if you're feeling really self-indulgent. Or the chocolate, depending on the degree of complexity you're feeling. Don't overlook the regular either. Once I finally got over the croissants, I moved on to the Asian style pastries; this morning, I had the coconut roll which was light, fluffy, and not too sweet. I've also had the ham and cheese bun, which is the most convenient breakfast sandwich ever... for 95 cents. Their glass case is always full, and I'm going to keep going back and trying more things. Next on my list is the BBQ bun.Only tiny caveat: credit cards only for orders over $7.00. This doesn't sound like a lot  until you realize that it's the equivalent of two croissants, a cup of coffee, and a baguette. Trust me on that.

43.description: Have been going to this bakery for many years now.  Discovered it by accident  after shopping @ Viet Hoa Grocery Store across the street.  My mom & I were both hungry and this was the first in site. They are famous for their bun stuffed delicacy.  My person favorite is the Barbecue Pork Bun.  Really good tasting Chinese barbecue pork with a little bit of sauce inside, making it not soggy at all.  My mom always try for the Shu Mai Bun and the Hot Dog bun - yes like corn dog but BETTER!  The dough is wrapped around the hot dog.   The hot dog itself is really tasty.  I usually go for the Asian stuff but they also carry variety of other delicious pastries and other goodies.The place is small.  Majority of people i noticed just order and leave.   Parking is hard so i suggest you go park across the street (Viet Hoa).  They have some exotic drinks/shakes as well.  I love this place so much i told Peter (owner) to open a branch in the suburbs.  So far nothing has happened.   It's worth a drive.    Highly Recommended!!!

2.description: I've had LaPatisserie P bookmarked for a while and I finally stopped in and got a selection of everything!   Cookies, cakes and cream horns.  Everything looked great!Parking tough outside because of the construction.   This area is going to look great once it's done.The place is looking a little beat up these days.  Both outside and in.  Maybe they're waiting for the construction outside to finish before they clean up.  We'll see.  Well probably not me because I brought home all the treats and everyone said they were just ok.  The butterfly cookies tasted like lard and the cream horns didn't have much flavor.With all the choices available in the area I'm moving on.

18.description: My mom's bday and she wants dinner in the city?  Considering she lives in the burbs and has never enjoyed the drive into the city, this was a surprise and unheard of.We go ahead and lock in the restaurant, and decide we definitely need to get her a cake of some sort, seeing that it's one of the more important birthday!  (You know, 1st, 18th, 21st, 30th, 45th, 50th, 65th, etc.)Trusty yelp leads me to La Patisserie!  While their online presence/website really is no help at all with regards to options/choices, the lady on the phone was plenty friendly and took the time to go through the different cake varieties.  Mango/passion fruit mousse chocolate cake.  Yup.  Done and done.  The chocolate layers were soft and lightly flavored, which was a perfect compliment to the smooth and fragrant flavors of mango and passion fruit mousse that served as thick top layer over the cake.  Verdict:  Mom loved the red bean sesame balls (her favorite dessert) which I tricked her into believing was her cake substitute.  She liked the actual cake even more!  Win win.Bonus:  It's a Chinese/Filipino bakery with French technique, so they were able to write "Happy Birthday Mom" in Chinese for us... and some of those Filipino snacks looked pretty divine.  Perhaps the wife and I need to make our way back for some snacks...

41.description: Great desserts and bread, a little bit on the pricey side.

52.description: I've been a fan of this place before the name change and still love it! The ham and cheese buns, bbq pork buns, and the shu mai buns are my favorite! They were just as good as when I was 5 years old and now that I'm in my 20s I still crave for them! These easily disappear within a day of being brought! HmmMmmm I can go for some right now!

50.description: La Patisserie P how I love you! The croissants are amazing, but what I can't get enough of are the bbq pork sandwiches. At only 95 cents, how can you go wrong? The curry chicken sandwich, also 95 cents, is like an on the go chicken pot pie. If you can warm it up a bit, even better. So buttery, so soft. Perfect size for a lunch. Or if you have a bigger appetite, get more than one. While I have tried the cakes and was not impressed, I still must give this place 5 stars. Go for the croissants or sandwiches. You will be amazed. I brought a student group here when we were studying about Vietnamese culture. While high school kids can be a bit tentative when exploring other food outside of the cheet-o group, my students LOVED the sandwiches. I think they bought out the place and this was after we had eaten at Pho 777!

4.description: I never want to go back to this place again. Service was horrendous! I am very disappointed to see how much this place has changed.I was looking for douhua (tofu-like soup) and had asked whether they had any available. The cashier told me "no," but then some domineering woman in the back yelled at her and told her they did. She came over with two custard looking things. I had my suspicions in wasn't the correct item, but I trusted that she knew best. I wanted one without sugar for my grandma who is diabetic. The woman told me they already had sugar in it. Then the other woman pushed her out of the way and claimed she could make it without sugar. She just poured the sugar syrup off the top of cup, but the sugar had definitely mixed in with the tofu already. So the woman rang me up and tried to swipe the money out of my hand without telling me how much it cost. I kept asking and she seemed annoyed when she finally had to tell me the price (which by the way is overpriced compared to most bakeries). The food item she gave me was not douhua. I am very annoyed that they sold me some sort of knock-off just to get my business. What bothers me most is that they tried to peddle off something as sugar free by simply pouring off the top layer of syrup when it had obviously incorporated into the dessert. I take health concerns very seriously and I wish they did too.Have no plans to ever support this place again.

6.description: The street in front is being renovated so it was difficult to know where to park and where not to park.  It is a cute little shop with a good amount of variety.  However, as i was checking out the backed goods, i did see a small fly behind the glass.  I am a bit of a germ freak so that put me off.  I kept my order very simple and ordered from the cold items.

22.description: I only like the raisin and chocolate almonds croissants , the lady there with eye glasses has a very bad attitude and pushy every time I go there she changes her prices all the time and pushes you to buy others things not going back , don't deserve the one star !!

15.description: La Patisserie P is a family-run bakery. There is a wide selection of buns and pastries. For $3.95 each, we had a piece of tiramisu cheesecake and chocolate ganache cake. For $2.95 each, we had a piece of mango cheesecake, caramel pecan tart, lemon meringue tart, and mocha napoleon. In total, our order was approximately $22.   The cake were on par. They were small and not heavily-sweetened. The mocha napoleon was flakey and had many layers. It was very bland although it had a sweet mocha aroma. The lemon meringue tart was not particularly sour. The flavors had a lighter edge. The caramel pecan tart was the highlight of the batch. It wasn't overly sweet but it was very rich. Would definitely return for this caramel pecan tart!

57.description: Came here to buy some breakfast for my coworkers. Bought the chocolate and the chocolate almond croissants. Everyone loved it. Came back another time to buy some desserts for family dinner. I bought tiramisu and creme brulee. Both were good but we all agreed the creme brulee was better.

20.description: i forgot how totes awes this place is.  you've got your plethora of asian pastries and treats: bbq pork buns (the brown buns, obvi, are the best kind of buns, awwww yeah), ensymada (a light puffy bun covered in butter and sugar), almond cookies (i can only assume there are almonds and cookie dough in it), sesame balls (balls covered in sesame, awwww yeah) and some sort of AWESOME CREAM PUFF thing filled with, well, cream.  crazy delish. it's so cheap.  we got a lotta stuff to go, for like, $16.  stupid cheap.  the staff is SO nice.

36.description: After eating so much food at the Pho Restaurant, we tried to walk around and of course, we stopped at a bakery to buy some snacks for later. This place is a fusion between European and Asian treats and they were all really good! i got a BBQ Pork Bun and an Egg tart as my usuals, but then I got a butter fly cookie with a nutella almond biscotti. All of it was so good and it was really inexpensive as well!This place looks really clean and the quality of the products were amazing for such a cheap price. I have to go 1.5 hours to travel all the way over here, but it was worth it! I would come here all the time if I lived closer! They also do custom cakes and with how great the other foods were, I would trust them here.

14.description: I was in the mood for something not-so-sweet, so I went here, since it's so close to where I live, and bought 3 croissants.  They weren't terribly impressive, if I'm being honest.  But I will come back here when I get a craving for something sweet, as I imagine this is where their strength resides.update:  My boyfriend and I finally gave this place another shot... and his lemon tart and my caramel walnut pastry were both delicious.  I'll adjust my star-rating.

58.description: This has always been my goto for Asian groceries, even when I lived 3 hours away. Great selection on produce, meat, and seafood. I can get everything I need in one location. Except they never have the small, yellow candles I need for daily worship at home (Buddhism). What I like:- Selection of produce and meat/seafood- Low prices- Snack foods- Convenient location; close to Vietnamese restaurants and take outsWhat I don't like:- Extremely busy- The craziest, tiniest parking lot

56.description: This place smells like armpits, feet, and death. The floor is filthy and the produce is questionable. However, the asian candy selection is awesome. Looking for golden or white rabbit? Looking for mochi? They have all this in a seperate aisle. Thing to look for the "double duck egg". I have no idea what it is, and from the looks of it I have no desire to either.

29.description: A great nice sized market! For those in the North Shore this is my favorite Asian market that is also conveniently accessible via El. I haven't been coming here since HMart is an easier drive, but I needed Vietnamese ingredients and this place was a safer bet that I'd find it all.I'd call this place a Vietnamese market first, and Asian grocer second. Basically, if it's a Vietnamese staple, there will be lots of it, lots of variety at a cheap price. Or if it's a Vietnamese specialty item, I'd look here first. But Chinese/East Asian stuff, there is sometimes only one brand of some things, though I'd say that they do at least stock most of the popular Pan-Asian items.Some examples:-Readily available beef bones for broth yay!-All the pho spices, some come in a package that's labeled "soup spices" in Chinese, but upon closer examination they're all the pho spices. Super convenient for me since I wouldn't have to buy a bunch of spices I don't normally cook with only to have them go stale in my pantry.-MANGOSTEEN. For $8/lb and not so fresh, but holy crap I can't believe they sell these in Chicago. (Other hard to find Southeast Asian specialty fruits too!)-Prepacked basil, mint, perilla, etc for really cheap. -Jars/packets of Vietnamese marinades and pastes that I don't typically see elsewhere.-Balut eggs, for the more adventurous. And fresh duck eggs. Yum!Another thing to look out for is bulk restaurant-supply-esque items. If you ever want a huuuuuge burlap sack of dried chilis for $12 or giant jugs of soy sauce for cheap, you know where to go! They also sell sleeves of take out containers for a reasonable price here.Organization is not so great, but its a small store filled with cool stuff for a really reasonable price, so don't be afraid to browse and look around!

42.description: I just relocated to Chicago 2 years ago, I miss Asian food a lot as we don't get the authentic one at the restaurants in the city except China town. One day my "Chef" friend took me to Tai Nam, I was surprised that they have every spices and ingredients of every country in Asia. Now I keep recommending friends and relatives to go there to get anything you need for your Asian Delicacy.

23.description: Big selection. Prices are ok. Flypaper is out with flies caught on it next to open bins with unwrapped fish. Wonder if that would pass an inspection. Good enough but there're better Asian groceries in the northwest suburbs.

47.description: It's an Asian grocery store so the environment is expected to be messier than Whole Foods. But when it comes to produce, meat, condiments, and Asian snacks, this place can satisfy most of your needs.
