Their prices were generally low, and I think this market compares well against its counterparts in the Chinatown area.On a side note, don't get put off by their fish selection. Smelly as it is, its quality is still quite decent.Side note No. 2: be aware of your wallet/purse. Sometimes pickpockets may party here. Hit'em with fish if you see something happens.

8.description: I came here on a Sunday afternoon with a few friends and was pleasantly surprised at the variety and prices at this Asian Market. It seems pretty busy, but well stocked with all sorts of recognizable and more unique items, from an aisle of rice and noodles to bags of dried fungi to an unbelievably large sack of Jasmine tea! I picked up some vermicelli noodles to try a homemade pad thai, and then went sauce crazy! Man oh man I love dipping sauces, and couldn't help but pile in some duck sauce, plum sauce, sesame sauce, and sriracha, and that was limiting myself! Plus some frozen potstickers to dunk in all those fancy sauces. I also snagged a Mandarin stir-fry sauce mix for 50 cents! They have meats and all sorts of whole fish, but personally the fish did not look its freshest to me, the eyes all looked kind of cloudy. However, I bet their live crabs and lobsters are just fine. I also got some great produce: a bunch of fresh cilantro for 50 cents, scallion bunch for 50 cents, a piece of fresh ginger for 40 cents, and a whole young coconut for less than $3! I quickly perused the back snack aisles and forcibly made myself walk by the six different delicious looking varieties of Pocky Sticks, but picked up a bag of fortune cookies for less than $1 as well. You can also pick up rice cookers, bowls, plates, etc, all sorts of equipment and serving items too. For a whole basket of things, I only ended up paying about $20 for all my great  finds. If you can survive the crowded parking lot and supermarket-sweep like aisles, this is a good bet for finding all your Asian grocery needs.

31.description: I usually just go to this market for canned/processed foods - eel, fried gluten, pork sung - and they are usually pretty well-stocked, although I would say that sometimes they are a little inconsistent with brands - sometimes they'll have exactly the brand and type that I want, sometimes they won't.

34.description: i don't care that people kick and elbow me and throw live prawn at me. the prices justify it all.  great veggies, noodles, tofu, rice. etc. whatever we need and more. didn't have thai curry but we forgave b/c large bag of basil was 1.43

16.description: Located in New Chinatown, this is another great hole-in-the-wall grocery store for your Vietnamese or general Asian desires. Parking in the lot is a bit tricky since it's always packed, but at least there is someone directing traffic.Once you get into the store, this is about as authentic as it gets. Hope you don't mind rude asian ladies and trying to get through aisles with more than two carts in it. If that hasn't deterred you yet, then you are on your way to a new, wonderfully weird world of asian groceries.Sure you have your standard snacks like Pocky, but how about learning to make your own Pho? All the ingredients can be found in this store. Check out the dessert section close to the entrance of the store, which will open up a whole new view of sweetness.If you're strong of heart, courageous in battle, and adventurous in taste, make your way over to Tai Nam. Earn your asian grocery store cred badge.

13.description: I popped in hoping to score a banh mi without feeling robbed blind like BaLe makes me feel, but... It was a Wednesday evening and there were none in sight. So I meandered around and picked up a bunch of junk food. Here's a quick rundown of my loot.Luck's Food Egg Tarts, sooooo tasty! Perfection. Che Khoai Mon dessert cup (coconut milk, sweet rice, taro and sugar). Yum! Thick and rich, slightly sweet. Only $2!Com Ruou. Tiny rice balls in liquid (dried rice, yeast and sugar). Odd. Very yeasty. I need to drown them in sweetened condensed milk or something. But ill probably pitch em before I do that. Luck's Food Banh Bo (Rice Cake with Sugar). I get these in Chinatown, too. Not all are created equal. Can't stand dry ones! Most pieces of these pieces were moist. A couple ends just a bit dry, but overall these were a good specimen of rice cakes. Grocery Goods: 1) Cha'i Pow Yu (braised gluten). This comes in at tin. Total vegetarian  junk food, but I like it. They sell a curry flavor variety here! 2) Canned bamboo shoot halves (shrugging my shoulders, why not?) 3) Instant Sizzling Rice Squares. Looks like they could be fun. 4) Banana Cream Biscuits (yummy artificially created fake-banana-flavored cream, sandwiched between butter crackers... For $1.49, why not?)That's all she wrote, folks. I'll return. Perhaps I'll have better luck finding $3.75 banh mi on a Saturday. The stock boys and checkout ladies are all very friendly. :)

11.description: One of the cleanest, most accessible, and well stocked Asian grocery stores in Uptown.  There's free parking, though it's competitive on weekends; and, it's located very close to the Argyle red line stop for those using public transportation.  As someone who is used to Asian grocery stores, this one has to be my favorite by far.

39.description: This is the best asian grocery by me - fresh produce at rock-bottom prices.  Minus one star because the parking situation is consistently crappy.  I hate having to fight for parking!Parking aside, Tai Nam does have an amazing selection of all sorts of asian foods - chinese, viet, korean, japanese, etc.  Their meat/fish selection is the only not-so-great part.  Looks sketchy.  I come for the tofu, noodles, bean sprouts (super fresh!), and asian greens.

37.description: This is probably the busiest grocery store in Viet town marked by a line of cars waiting to get inside the packed parking lot on a Sunday.  Free parking is scarce in this area so people do crazy things just to park for free in a private lot as opposed to metered street parking.The interior is quite large for a local grocery store and contains everything from housewares to fresh seafood still swimming in tanks, fresh cuts of meat, and exotic produce. There are aisles and aisles of various Asian dried goods but watch out for items that are years beyond the expiration date. I found a package of noodles dating back to mid 2010!As with any grocery store, some thing can be found very cheap while other items are marked up in order to squeeze a margin out of your total sale so it's smart to do a little price research before assuming that everything is cheaper just because it's a privately owned grocery store.If you're looking to just take a look around to walk off that huge bowl of pho you just slurped down your throat, this is the perfect place to do it. Just don't try parking in their lot.

0.description: All fresh Asian ingredients is here at this spot. Great value, great price. Open daily & free parking.

38.description: Pretty cramped up asian supermarket. The people at the register here are not customer friendly. I was standing there in front of the person at the register with others waiting behind me and the lady kept on having a conversation of unimportantance not paying attention to her job. There's also another Tai Nam page on yelp same place just different page. The reviews on that page are more accurate, see for yourself.

51.description: This is my new favorite Asian grocery.  I came here looking for green papaya and found exactly what I needed.  The store is well stocked, well organized, and clean, with appealing produce.  I will definitely be coming back here in the future for my asian food needs.

27.description: 4.75 stars*I recently took a trip to Thailand and was very excited to come back and attempt to recreate some of the experience.  Before shopping, I scoured the reviews, and Broadway Supermarket seemed like a good option.  Tai Nam looked good too (both 4 stars), and there wasn't much out there in terms of comparing or contrasting the two of them.  I went to Broadway first, and Tai Nam a month or so later, and I think Tai Nam wins hands down.  The Tai Nam highlights:-Organization: This place was a dream to walk through in comparison to Broadway; well organized, methodically laid out, and (shudder) things were labeled.  That's a big deal when you're not an expert in identifying things.-Noodles/rice: There is an exceptionally awesome row of the largest variety of dry noodles I have ever seen.  A ton of options in bean thread, many brown rice varieties, all shapes and sizes, and origin.  The rice was organized well too, which was great because I could not find reasonably sized sticky rice at Broadway; sushi rice, black rice, red rice, rice rice rice. Great dried spring roll wrapper options too (at least 10 varieties and differing sizes/shapes).  Fresh noodle roughly on par with Broadway, although another option or two for sheet noodle.-Canned goods: an exceptional aisle of canned fruits (jackfruit at least 5 different ways), far surpassing Broadway.  At least another dozen types of bamboo shoots, and more types of canned mushrooms than I could imagine (but given the fresh mushroom selection here, not of concern).-Produce: Impressive selection and good price; found long beans, and green papaya easily; herbs were plentiful (culantro, basil, mint, etc.) and priced well (this may become an herb haven for me); taro, durian, dragon fruit, mango varieties, etc.  They sell thai chilis in a small packet for 99 cents so no need to take home 50 like at Broadway. Good variety of mushrooms (though admittedly that day I didn't like the look of the oyster so opted for king oyster); meiji, enoki too.-Meat: Good selection, and I would buy it, (which I didn't feel comfortable with at Broadway based on smell alone); head on chicken; duck at $2.60 a pound, live lobster and crab, as well as frozen options.-Supplies: they have a nice selection of cooking supplies if you need anything (say a gigantic mortar and pestle for som tum)-Sauces/Curry pastes: this was maybe the only weak point; they did have less variety in sauces than Broadway, but that only seems to be an issue if you're hunting for something very specific.  Curry pastes were well organized and they had a broad variety, but for the larger tubs Mae Ploy is the option as opposed to Maesri (should that matter to you).In summary, I was walking on sunshine after leaving Tai Nam.  I will most assuredly be back.  They have a busy parking lot on the weekends, but as others have said, the street parking/el may be worth it instead.*A slight deduction in enthusiasm for a red pepper I bought which turned out to be past its prime (ick) once I cut into it.

32.description: My go to Asian grocer.  They have everything I need for all my asian recipes.  I've shopped the neighborhood for years and time and time again, I come back to Tai Nam.Clams, crawfish, butcher, lemongrass, bun bo hue, pho, fish sauce, siracha, coconut milk

54.description: I am still not certain why a couple workers laughed when I asked if the store carries Galangal. I likely mispronounced it. Maybe galangal is to ginger is what the parsnip is to the carrot: ignored by the majority of the local population. My current cursory breakdown of local Asian grocers goes something like this. Golden Pacific is more accessible. Broadway Market has better fish. Tai Nam sells fresh Kaffir Leaves!

48.description: I've been coming here for Asian groceries since I was a kid. Luckily, it hasn't changed much since then except now they have automatic doors, shopping carts, and they just started selling lotto tix. I like coming here to buy vegetables, fish, tea, snacks, and some pastries. When I compare the prices with the other asian grocery stores in the area, this place will usually have the best prices among them depending on the item. My goto place to shop is Tai Nam, but my 2nd option Viet Hoa for certain items.BTW parking here on weekends is a real pain. We usually try to go here during the week when there aren't as many people around.

44.description: If I have to drive an hour and a half and wait for 30 min just to look for parking in this place, I'll do it again for the next visit...again and again.  It's worth the trip.  I like the fresh food and seafood they sell.  Reminiscence of a Filipino "Palangke" minus the wet market.  And after you're done doing grocery, try to stop by on the Pho place they got next door.  Their serving bowl is beyond belief....it's actually good to serve for 2-3 people!

24.description: congrats to the lucky mega millions second prize of 1 million winner!

7.description: As many of you have noticed, I've been obsessing to making Chinese-style hot pot.  Nevertheless, traveling all the way from Albany Park to Chinatown isn't always feasible.  I discovered the alternative solution.  Tai Nam was the chosen destination in finding hot-pot appropriate essentials.  We went on a non-festive Saturday afternoon, and it was packed with customers.  We grabbed a shopping buggy, even though the some aisles could barely fit one (1) cart.  However, customers were professional in cart-pushing and everyone was in his/her zone shopping.  We got some frozen Vietnamese-style beef, shrimp, and fish balls, some little frozen fish (super bony), a large bundle of bok choy, a bag of seafood mix, three (3) different kinds of hot-pot soup base, a small jar of Chinese barbecue sauce, a small container of spicy bean curds (very salty as well), two (2) Vietnamese specialty food from their ready-to-eat section (one being a dessert type of item), and two (2) packs of Vietnamese-style instant noodles.  I think I might have left out some items that I failed to include; this was pretty much the summary of things we purchased.  The total came to $48 after tax.  I thought it was pretty good deal considering more than half of the items were saved for the next hot-pot feast.  Some say Chinese lacks customer-service skills.  Well, I should say Vietnamese will take a lead in that category.  The cashier was talking to the bagger the entire time in Vietnamese while she was checking us out.  She could care less, really.  So what?  This is a grocery store.  Get what you want, and get out!  I would still prefer Hong Kong Market, but Tai Nam is definitely a great option since it's only a short-bus ride away from our apartment.  The CTA 81 Lawrence will take you to Broadway, and then it's a short walk north to the Uptown Vietnamese village.

49.description: I like coming here to buy Filipino and other Asian snacks, spices and sauces. The fish they have for sale scares me because it smells like fish (which is bad) and so far the fish I saw is far from fresh. I'd stray away from anything like that. The fruit is cool they have Pitaya! Pitaya doesn't really come from dragons nor do they use it as fruit. Kinda deceiving. The prices here are awesome, but I find it interesting to see some Asians using link cards then rolling out in Lexus and Mercedes vehicles. Anywho this place is cool try it. I give it three for no fresh fish and no sample Saturdays or Sundays.

40.description: This was our go to market when I was growing up as a child, mind you we never leave near here, but we always drove that 45mins on those crazy, busy Sunday mornings to shop here. Being a kid I always like to mess with the fresh live crab and find those yummy pocky sticks that I'll casually put into my mom's cart. There's a lot of fresh produce to choose from and great cuts of meat, fish, and seafood. For that reason the smell can be intolerable to some.Aisles are kept clear and can often be tight with shoppers on Sundays and sometimes in those moment you wish you were a kid again so you can squeeze through those tight spots. I say be adventurous and check this place out with an open mind, you'll never know what you'll find and heck maybe try and make an Asian dish.

53.description: Cheap and excellent selection.  I am only disappointed because we moved to the south suburbs so I only get to go up there every so often.  Tai Nam Food Market is my favorite grocery store.  Their fish selection is amazing.

30.description: This is a great local Asian grocer. There are aisles and aisles of imported food. And a great selection of fresh fish. Also a fairly large selection of produce. They do a parking lot. But it's usually filled

46.description: Good options for asian groceries. When I am in the area I always make a stop and pick up a few necessities.

1.description: For anyone on the Northside that enjoys cooking "certain" Asian cuisines, Tai-Nam is one of the most consistently well-stocked, pleasant places to shop.  Stocked  primarily with groceries that are Southeast Asian, it can save you a schlep down to Chinatown when you're in a pinch.  Parking can be at a premium on the weekends, but there are numerous side streets off B'way with ample free parking. There's definitely a method to the madness at Tai-Nam.  Best day to shop for fresh fish is THURSDAY.  Mid-week and weekends are the best produce days.  Largest selection of Vietnamese bakery items (both savory and sweet)  are available on Saturday & Sunday.  Those steamed rice noodles with shrimp, pork, & veggies ( served with dipping sauce) are awesome.

55.description: Love this store. Seems small on the outside--might be due to the crazy parking lot others have mentioned--but they've got a great selection.First, I don't recommend driving there. With the Broadway bus and Red Line right there--and you're not far from the 151 or even the 146 and 147--it's pretty easy to get to for the most part.Mainly, I go for their selection of ramen/instant noodles. (My favorite are the instant udon for $0.75.) Lately I've been getting a bag of plain buns for $1.85, those plus the chocolate "CeReal" make a great breakfast.Haven't gotten the fresh produce here, but as far as packaged & frozen foods? It's awesome. It's my main store for groceries.

9.description: Like the majority of reviewers, this is my go-to Asian grocery store.  It's super busy almost all the time - I really can't remember a time I breezed into the parking lot without waiting for a spot.  The best thing to do is just park on the street and pay the meter in my opinion which is what I usually do.  I come here for basil (they're always fresh) and to stock up on Vermicelli noodles, Soy sauce... as well as tea and some other yummy treats you can't find at your local Jewel or Whole Foods.  It's a ways from where I live, but I definitely make it a point to stop in whenever I'm in the area.

26.description: To others it's may seem great but I've been to others that were better and this seems to be the only known Asian market known to us since we moved to IL. We drive about an hour and half to come here (Used to be 40 min but we moved father away) Anyways, this is a small grocery store and parking lot is ALWAYS full or pack which is a con! Also, when they ring up your prices be sure to WATCH&CHECK bc they do go fast when checking out and can rip you off on your purchase! I think they do it on purpose though. I also think they are very cheap in their bag usage and when we KNOW our bags is going to rip we ask for it to be double but they always say it's not that heavy or it's ok or my manager will yell at me ..happened to my mom a few times and she tells them off and they end up just double bagging it. I also think this grocery store is expensive due to imported goods. This place also seem run down in shelves and flooring . Not a great store to look at but to buy its decent in other words. I mean they could fix up the place to make it look more appearing and reasonable. But other than that its OK!!!!

25.description: Located in New Chinatown, this is another great hole-in-the-wall grocery store for your Vietnamese or general Asian desires. Parking in the lot is a bit tricky since it's always packed, but at least there is someone directing traffic.Once you get into the store, this is about as authentic as it gets. Hope you don't mind rude asian ladies and trying to get through aisles with more than two carts in it. If that hasn't deterred you yet, then you are on your way to a new, wonderfully weird world of asian groceries.Sure you have your standard snacks like Pocky, but how about learning to make your own Pho? All the ingredients can be found in this store. Check out the dessert section close to the entrance of the store, which will open up a whole new view of sweetness.If you're strong of heart, courageous in battle, and adventurous in taste, make your way over to Tai Nam. Earn your asian grocery store cred badge.

12.description: Huge Vietnamese grocery market. Parking attached. You will be very confused if you are not familiar with Vietnamese food/ ingredients. I wish I knew more about it also. But it is still a very interesting place to visit, we always get asian snacks from the place.Great selections of vegetables meets seafoods and everything. however the place need to consider hygiene more. the guy working in the meat corner grabbed pork belly with his barehand- no gloves or anything.

59.description: I have been going to Viet Hoa for my Asian food needs for years-- but I might make a change to Tai Nam!  The aisles are clean and wide enough to walk through with a cart, which is a incredible feat to accomplish at Viet Hoa.  Although the tight quarters may be the charm at my other place, it is really hard to beat the brand variety, cleanliness, and parking availability at Tai Nam.  The seafood selection is excellent, the crabs are still moving in the box, Filipino pastries are fresh, and the little Village Creamery fridge is always stocked, my only complaint is that my favorite flavor (cheese!) isn't usually there.

21.description: My family does most of our shopping for asian groceries here. It's a little dingy, but the prices are great and there's a good selection. I also appreciate that they have deserts and other freshly made ready-to-eat food. However, the parking on a busy day is quite a nightmare. The wait is long because the lot is small. People tend to drive pretty recklessly too, but overall a great place!

17.description: I love Tai Nam and shop here regularly as a chef.  We recently did a "Culinary Throwdown" similar in nature to Chopped and I bought a whole lot of interesting stuff here.  They used Rambutan, rice vermicelli, ginger, and a bunch of other ingredients that we bought at Devon (the Indian stuff).  Back to Tai Nam.  I rely on this store for my home life and for use teaching.  The price points are incredible plus they carry Lan Chi Garlic Chili paste which I find incomparable and is a main ingredient in my tuna tartare. I can't say enough good about this place and I also don't know if I'll ever try every single thing in there.  Oh yeah, they also have Cafe Du Monde, and usually quail eggs. Wonderful place.

10.description: We stop here after we eat pho to grab a few Asian veggies and snacks. We have been able to find Taiwanese pickled veggies and an assortment of other things here so they seem to have a good variety of non Vietnamese food. I have never purchased meat/ fish here, but I have bought lots of fresh herbs, ginger, scallions, and processed/jarred items. They also have a few shelves for fresh Vietnamese desserts. I can never resist. The sticky black rice with coconut sauce was delicious. I also got a coconut taro sweet soup last time that I devoured in seconds. The desserts are a big draw for me.

5.description: Very Good Asian/Vietnamese supermarket with a parking lot at the side. Veggies fresh and decent prices for shiitake mushrooms, Chinese broccoli, bok Choi. Lots of Thai and Vietnamese dry goods, pastes, noodles, rice. They have a decent fresh fish section too. Not as extensive as the markets in Queens or Jersey City but really not bad at all. Checkout friendly and quick.

3.description: Always a fun place to be, i love the fresh vegetables and its affordable too.

35.description: the grocery store is perfectly situated off the argyle red line stop, and near the argyle chinatown restaurants.  all their produce are fresh, and reasonably priced.  especially their herbs (i.e thai spicy basil, mint, cilantro) , you can find around $1.  i know a lot of the leading chains charge significantly more for these items.  they have fresh seafood in its whole form, and not frozen.  as a food enthusiast, this is very important for me as it doesn't change the flavor of the seafood.  the local bakery also sell their fresh goods at this market making this shop a one stop shop for just about everything.  tucked away in the back is a small houseware section selling pots, pans, dishes, and utensils for fraction of the cost as well.  chopsticks, check!  teapot, check!  a small saucepan, check!  definitely a treasure in the city for those of us who are on a budget.(warn of caution: stay away from durian fruit.  i'm sorry.. that's the one thing i can never get past).

19.description: This is the go-to-spot for Vietnamese groceries. They have fresh seafood, fresh vegetables, fresh sweets, and fresh everything for reasonable prices. It gets crowded in here but that says a lot of the quality of their produce - people like it! They always have many of their cash registers open which is nice to keep the lines diluted and moving. I recommend this place! Oh and free parking!

28.description: perfect selection and location.  near the argyle station on the red line.  found lots of asian spices that you cannot find in chinatown.  the prices are also very reasonable.  will be back for sure.

45.description: I just shopped at Tai Nam market for the first time a few weeks ago. The shelving was very organized and I found the items on my list with more ease than expected. When I couldn't find something,  one of the employees was very friendly and helped out. Now this whole experience was  pummeled by the horrid cashier who only had what seemed to be resentment or disgust, maybe both, for me. She was extremely nice to the customers ahead of me so the drastic attitude change was more than noticeable. I'll try another market to see if the cashier is somewhat nice or even cordial.

33.description: Store Review:Bustling supermarket but cheap groceries. If you want your fill of asian groceries/snack items this is the place to be. Avoid trying to get your car into the parking lot because it is a mess, instead park at the paybox lot in the adjacent street and walk over. This is a rather large asian grocery store with a broad selection of vietnamese/chinese grocery items including noodles, sauces, fresh fish, and a large selection of snack items. The prices are reasonable, but watch your wallet in this tight store. There are signs everywhere be careful of pickpocketers. Overall checkout is fast and they take credit card. Pros- cheap asian grocery, fresh vegetables and fish, free lot (I would avoid at all cost though)Cons- Difficult to move around store, beware of pickpocketers as the sign saysHidden deals- Free parking lot, but super busy

43.description: Are you a Thai food enthusiast who really needs help finding those ingredients?Come here!  The store has almost everything you can imagine, plus durian fruit, which I'm still intrigued by but afraid to bring into my home for fear of the smell.The store manager is really friendly and will help you find what you are looking for, and always point you to the best/freshest product.  My only wish is that they would carry fresh flat wide rice noodles for making pad see ewe.  They carry fresh flat wide wheat noodles, which works, but the texture isn't the same as something you would buy from a restaurant.Bonus: they sell a lot of cheap pots, pans, bowls, and chopsticks!  I got a wok for $15! Go here!

2.description: Tai Nam is the best. It'll save the residents of the northside a trip to Chinatown as they have a lot of the same foods. And they're way cheaper. Their produce is pretty great. I always leave with bean sprouts, ginger, cilantro, and mint at least... because it's always fresh. The snack and tea aisles are to die for. I also learned that there are hundreds of different flavors of instant noodles. My pantry is now always stocked with mi goreng and tom yum. A lot of time I'm not completely sure what I'm buying, but that's half the fun!Might want to avoid going on a weekend though, because it will be PACKED. Honestly, their parking lot makes me glad that I left my car in the suburbs.

18.description: A great nice sized market! For those in the North Shore this is my favorite Asian market that is also conveniently accessible via El. I haven't been coming here since HMart is an easier drive, but I needed Vietnamese ingredients and this place was a safer bet that I'd find it all.I'd call this place a Vietnamese market first, and Asian grocer second. Basically, if it's a Vietnamese staple, there will be lots of it, lots of variety at a cheap price. Or if it's a Vietnamese specialty item, I'd look here first. But Chinese/East Asian stuff, there is sometimes only one brand of some things, though I'd say that they do at least stock most of the popular Pan-Asian items.Some examples:-Readily available beef bones for broth yay!-All the pho spices, some come in a package that's labeled "soup spices" in Chinese, but upon closer examination they're all the pho spices. Super convenient for me since I wouldn't have to buy a bunch of spices I don't normally cook with only to have them go stale in my pantry.-MANGOSTEEN. For $8/lb and not so fresh, but holy crap I can't believe they sell these in Chicago. (Other hard to find Southeast Asian specialty fruits too!)-Prepacked basil, mint, perilla, etc for really cheap. -Jars/packets of Vietnamese marinades and pastes that I don't typically see elsewhere.-Balut eggs, for the more adventurous. And fresh duck eggs. Yum!Another thing to look out for is bulk restaurant-supply-esque items. If you ever want a huuuuuge burlap sack of dried chilis for $12 or giant jugs of soy sauce for cheap, you know where to go! They also sell sleeves of take out containers for a reasonable price here.Organization is not so great, but its a small store filled with cool stuff for a really reasonable price, so don't be afraid to browse and look around!

41.description: Produce is inexpensive and good quality.

52.description: If you want cheap and good full leaf tea, this place is good, but other than that i cannot find anything useful for myself. However, I can admit that it was so crowded when i visited it, it means some people like this place ;)

50.description: Tai Nam is possibly the best Vietnamese store in the Argyle area because I could find almost anything Vietnamese and Thai there. Sauces, meat,seafood, dry goods, snacks, vegetables, and rare herbs, you name it. Some South East Asian food items are available but Indian ingredients are not widely offered though. I love buying squid and prawns that are on sale here, and all my other Asian ingredient needs. In fact, Tai Nam is my go to grocery before I try anywhere else. I hope to see them expand in the future years.

4.description: This grocery store has a slew of Asian foods and it's only Asian food. There are a lot of variety and exotic foods. I think this place is medium-priced, but I don't mind. It's hard to find these type of foods; I pay more for what is rare here. The laws of supply and demand...gotta love it.This place is in Uptown so just be careful when you're walking around the neighborhood. I wouldn't call it dangerous, but there are a lot of people  asking for money and they will get really close to you to do it. Parking can be pretty bad. It really depends on when you go. The worst times to go is on the weekends in the afternoon. Luckily, there's a train stop around the corner (take the red line and get off the Argyle station).

6.description: This supermarket is intense. Especially on a Sunday morning when everyone and their mother is shopping here. The parking situation in the lot was out of control and a long line of cars trying to park. It was super crowded at the supermarket which made it a bit difficult to navigate the aisles with a stroller but we somehow managed. They have all the best Vietnamese groceries as well as quite a good selection of other Asian items. We were trying to find some Malaysian grocery items which we heard could be found here but only managed to find one thing. I'd like to go back when it's not crowded and take the time to discover more gems at this supermarket. We will return!

22.description: Good prices and selections. I just don't like the cashiers:1. They look like they are always in a bad mood2. kinda rude sometimes3. never look at you in the eye when they ask you to put your signature on the receipt4. throw your groceries into the bags not caring if they break or damage5. never change their dirty dirty gloves they weareww

15.description: Good prices and selections. I just don't like the cashiers:1. They look like they are always in a bad mood2. kinda rude sometimes3. never look at you in the eye when they ask you to put your signature on the receipt4. throw your groceries into the bags not caring if they break or damage5. never change their dirty dirty gloves they weareww

57.description: I used to shop at another market until I found Tai Nam - and I was a convert. I did a little bit checking in between and realized that this place is the cheapest for most of the products.What do I buy here? everything really...I go here to stock up on my greens: bok choi, okra, bean sprout, green onions, peppers, bitter melon, etc. They also have tons of herbs for all the asian cooking you'd like to do. I also love the meat and seafood sections here: You'd have to order your meat - and they're all vietnamese, but they understand sign language (point, show how many pounds you want by your fingers, nod, shake, etc.) Easy as a cake. Seafood - pick 'em up yourself. Fresh, that's the best thing you can ask for from seafood. Spices - much cheaper and basically everything you'd need and more. They also have lots and lots of cooking pastes, sauces (fish, soy, hot, etc.).Canned food - everything from mangosteen to fish - you imagine!Cooking utensils: I didn't expect much from a $12 wok we got here, but it's holding up great!Treats: Cookies, dried mango (my personal fav), candies, waffles, mochi ice-cream. YUUUMMMMM!!!Except for the smell and the somewhat dirty floor, I can't ask for more from a market. Avoid going during Sunday morning - from my experiences that is the busiest time. And Asians bring their whole family with them when going grocery shopping (yes - grandparents, uncles, sisters, cousins, children), and we're very populated too!

20.description: This is the go-to-spot for Vietnamese groceries. They have fresh seafood, fresh vegetables, fresh sweets, and fresh everything for reasonable prices. It gets crowded in here but that says a lot of the quality of their produce - people like it! They always have many of their cash registers open which is nice to keep the lines diluted and moving. I recommend this place! Oh and free parking!

36.description: Spotted the Asian market while grabbing dim sum across the street.  This place is bigger than the Chinatown market and seems to have more variety.Typical of Asian markets, it's crowded, dirty, a bit disorganized, but cheap and full of options.If it were closer to me, I'd probably frequent more often.

14.description: Just sold me a spoiled soybean milk drink. Parking isn't worth it, If you like complete vehicle stand stills (in and out) due to the incompetence of nothing but bad drivers have at it.

58.description: I really love this place.  I mainly go for the pies that they sell at the counter in the back of the store.  Since it's far from where I live, I typically stock up and stash various varieties in my freezer.  Since I don't eat meat I've only tasted the veggie varieties, and I like them all:  spinach and feta is a classic and really well done, parsley and feta is a little different and very flavorful, and I really enjoy the eggplant one and the artichoke/cheese ones too.  They're really great for a quick snack or light meal.  After a visit to the oven, they emerge fragrant and crispy on the outside, with their olive oil-rich bread crust.  Mmmmmm.  Their grocery selection is fun too--lots of beans, rice, prepared dips, etc.  For any of you who live nearby: I am jealous.  For anyone who is wondering if it's worth the trip:  I vote a solid yes.  And you might just run into Puppet Bike too!  Hopefully you won't get smacked on the head by a snow avalanche like I did, though...

56.description: Love this little middle eastern grocery / bakery.  I was doing long walking-around-neighborhood today so did not buy anything heavy or need refrigeration,  but looks like they have nice variety of home made foods such as hummus.  Bough stainless steel cezve to make Turkish coffee at home :-)     Would like to try their baked items next time.

29.description: Wow this grocery store is amazing. It's an easy to miss storefront, and I can't believe it's taken me this long to get there. There are a ton of hard-to-find spices and dried goods. I found three kinds of gul receli, this amazing rose petal jam I had in Turkey. Never thought I would be able to find it stateside! Also they carry coffee from one of the most famous Turkish coffee roasters. The juices and spices are great - you will pay twice the price elsewhere. I didn't have a chance to try their pies or desserts, but I will definitely be back!

42.description: If you are a fan of Middle Eastern fare, you need to make a trip to Middle Eastern Bakery. It's a small store stocked with spices, grains, coffee, prepared food, dried fruit and more. I get preserved lemons here that I use for cooking and can be hard to find. It also sells spices that are unavailable at your local grocery store. Their prepared deli and bakery food is excellent: spinach and feta pies, lentil soup, babaganoush, hummus, and more. It's also quite affordable. I'm so glad that I live within walking distance to this Andersonville gem. I heard they are expanding into the former crepe restaurant space and I'm looking forward to seeing their new expanded space.

23.description: Good store for take-out food for a picnic by the lake.

47.description: I think I could live off of their mini pizzas. I got five and ate them all in two days. (They're especially good when reheated in the oven!)Middle East Bakery is a plethora of spices and yummy goodies. This place is a gem, and I am so happy to have found it. Everything is delicious and very reasonably priced. Go here. Seriously. This place is worth it.

8.description: I can't say enough good things. I've been shopping at Middle East for at least 20 years.. The selection is amazing! Falafel, olives, meat pies, hummus, breads, spices and tons of snacks!! I could go on and on!And the owner is super, super nice.  He's adding on a restaurant. I can't wait!!!!!

31.description: Thanks to all of the reviews that mention it, I had to try the dill hummus. It's pretty solid. I think I like hummus with a bit more oil than this has, but that's easy - just pour a bit more on top! I also tried the spicy hummus (good) and an eggplant dip (so-so.) I have an eggplant pie & spinach pie to try later. The medium sized pitas I bought (5/$1.45) are a little dense and dry for my taste. I thought about getting the minis, which looked much fluffier, but for some reason I didn't. My mistake on that one. Some of the other breads looked amazing!For $3 you get a delicious 8 ounce container of hummus or dip, that's much better than grocery store brands, and if the pies are good (I'll know later) they will totally be worth the price (under $2 each.)Their spice selection is big and has some hard to find items (that you won't get at the regular grocery store.) I would definitely recommend this place for the hummus and dip selection!

34.description: I love to go here to get a lot of food when I know I am going to have a busy day or even a busy week. I can pick up plenty of snacks and good food to eat. My favorite is the smoky baba ganoush. I also really like the sesame seed flat bread, yum! I went there with my partner earlier this week to stock up for a day long road trip. We got our usual favorites, plus  one each of the new varieties of vegan hand pies they have. We had a great day eating all our wonderful snacks. I will continue to shopping here, and loving it.

16.description: I try to make biweekly trips to the Middle East Bakery & Grocery to pick up hummus, spicy babaghanuge, and their spinach and cheese pies, and lentil soup. YUM. The spicy babaghanuge never lasts long because I put it on everything. The lentil soup is perfectly lemony, yet savory, and total comfort food for me. A pie dipped in the spicy babaghanuge accompanied by a bowl of lentil soup is a satisfying and filling meal.My only complaint, nitpicky as it is, is that the store itself is a little crowded. They are in the process of expanding, but they are trying to stay open as much as possible during the expansion, and don't anticipate being closed more than two or three days. This will remedy the issue of the cramped quarters. Because the change, they seem to be reorganizing the shop. This complaint is only a testament to the large variety they carry.All in all, I love this place, but I love the feeling when I get home with a bag of awesome noms even more.

13.description: Stopped in yesterday to pick up some goodies.  The love hasn't died and in fact it's stronger than ever.  Try the lentil soup that's in the refrigerator case.  It's delightfully light, clean and lemony.  The lemony artichoke spread is addictive and wonderful on pita bread or pita chips.   I also got the lentil pie, as well as the spinach and onion pie.  So much portable tastiness in a neat little pocket.  I'm looking forward to the cafe opening, which they said should be open early summer.   It will be a great addition to the corner of Foster and Clark!

11.description: I love this place, I go once a week for a number of things. I am really looking forward to their expansion. I like to get my hummus, dips and gluteen free chips there. I also like the patties. Lamb and potato as well as the bean and lentil!

39.description: We love this place!  Great for stocking up on farro, rice, grains, and spices for CHEAP.We stopped by and picked up farro, aleppo pepper, veggie flatbreads, some pies, fig rolls, etc etc etc. and hardly spent $30.  We've been feasting on our finds ever since.  It's wonderful.  Wander around and find some stuff to put together a delicious dinner.  Go home and don't leave for two days.  Subsist on farro salad, eggs on pita, veggie pies.  Drink wine.  Sleep lots.  Highly recommend it.

37.description: Here is a secret - 3 mini vegan pizzas that'll melt in your mouth for $4

0.description: Yesssss. So much yes. It makes me happy to have a place like this in my neighborhood! I was *so* excited to bring my family here and they were *so* excited to find the golden hazelnut spread that they haven't seen since their childhood. It was pretty damn adorable to see their nostalgic reactions to trying something they haven't had since they left Turkey years and years ago. I definitely recommend the spices and deli selections as well. It's a great place to stock up on red pepper and the hummus and lentil soup are great. Excited to see what they do with the cafe section they are working on!

38.description: I went here today to buy some of their pies. I originally bought them with my late mother who got them at Whole Foods Market. It wasn't until today which was the first time going back in several years. I also like the fact that they carry a lot of things to make middle eastern dishes with. Its not hard to find this place since its conveniently located on Foster Avenue just a couple steps from Clark Street to the east and Ashland Avenue to the west. Its near bus lines and you may want to keep in mind that they do not have a lot so you will be parking on the street.  Its worth a visit for these pies they are delicious when gently warmed up. The staff was very friendly and helpful.

51.description: Oh man.Unsuspecting store front, potentially hidden on Foster to those who do not wander off Clark, make it your sole goal to visit this place next time you are wandering around Andyville.Everything I have purchased from here is absolutely delicious. Hit up the little "deli" counter in the back right corner where they have fresh made pies. When I say pie I do not mean PIE. I mean spinach and cheese pie, spinach and onion pie, lamb and onion pie, parsley and olive pie, etc. These bad boys are fresh, crazy delicious and cost about $1.75 and will fill you up. Quick, delicious, cheap lunch or dinner. Also behind this counter find olives and cheese. They have refrigerated cases filled with homemade soup, baba, hummus, taboulah, etc etc etc. Their vegetarian lentil soup is awesome. Don't miss the shelves of freshly made pita in all shapes and sizes. Oh, but you're not done there. There are also shelves filled with trays of the best sweets money can buy. Halva, honey cake, a thousand varieties of baklava in different shapes with different nuts. I don't care what anyone says, nuts, honey and rose water  = best desserts on earth. It's pretty hard to walk out of here without grabbing something sweet. There are other plastic containers with cookies, crackers, candied lemon, ginger and other stuff to drool over too. Grab a little copper coffee pot while you're here so you can make Turkish coffee at home. Get the small vacuumed sealed green and black coffee bag that says "With Cardamom" on it. TO DIE FOR. Fastest cup of coffee you'll ever make at home (well maybe, I don't have one of those K Cup Machines). Maybe I should say most rewarding cup for coffee you'll make at home with the richest, most delicious flavor. There are also aisles of dried beans, a million spices and herbs, and jars of tahini, honey, yogurt, hot pepper paste, rose water and more. It's basically the greatest place on earth and you should go here now. This place has changed my life.

27.description: This is the 2nd time my older sister has taken me here just to get her meat pies, Lamb & Potatoes, pickled turnips & beets. We were here on 10-3-14. I got to try 2 meatless pies one had feta cheese & olives & something else. My 2nd one was Spinach & Feta. Oh my, oh my. These are actually good. I like the  Spinach & Feta with a bit of sour cream. My sister says to try it with some pickled turnips & beets along with it. They are good also but so salty. I LOVE FETA CHEESE but a little goes a long way. When you walk in the store look to your right and go to the back of the store and you will see the metal counter that has the yummy meat pies. They make all of them in the store. They sell assorted teas, coffee's. herbs, spices, pita breads, assorted breads, candy ,nuts.

32.description: 20 minute weekly walk to pick up a steady supply of homemade hummus, olive tapenade, pita chips and various other items ... baklava, olive salads etc. I'd walk 45 minutes every day, if I had too. I'd never shopped at any other middle eastern grocer before, so I don't have anything to compare it too... and I hope I never have too.  I could live on their hummus and tapenade (sometimes I think I already do)

54.description: This place really knocked me right out of my socks.  Not filled with massive knowledge on Middle Eastern food - other than liking to gorge myself on it - so I can't be an authority.  However, whomever wants to keep buying that crappy hummus and tzatziki at the overly-crappy jewel on Clark and Bryn Mawr, be my guest.  More for me!  What can I say?  A wall of spices, homemade sauces, great prices, falafel, na'an, great prices, friendly people...I will definitely be back.

48.description: This place is filled with all sorts of goodies. It is definitely one of my favourite places in Chicago to pick up groceries and snacks. I always stock up when I go there. Great Zatar bread, great dips. My favourite are the spicy babaganoush and the imam bayeldi. Oh and the dill hummus. ALL so good. I wished I lived next to it. If you have not been here, you are missing out.

44.description: I was already in major like with MEB.At least once a month, I make the trek, i.e., take the Red Line up north to the Berwyn stop, then on foot some more up Broadway, then Foster (though if you have patience, you can probably catch a bus) till I reached the hallowed, albeit nondescript, storefront that is MEB.Time to load up.Upon first impression, it might look like nothing, until you peruse the shelves, then there is always something.  I "discovered" Omur yogurt here. It is a plain Turkish yogurt with cream on the top.  Holy cow, this stuff is heavenly!  Brown Cow does not compare.  Sadly, on my most recent trip, they were out, and not sure when they would receive another shipment, though the order is in.  Hopefully, soon.  I love the deli in the back and the variety of savory pies they have to offer.  Thanks to this deli, I was finally able to try kibbeh. They offer the typical meat kibbeh, but also a vegetarian variety made with spinach.  I love the contents of the refrigerator case: vegetarian potato soup, THE BEST lentil soup, cheese, olives, dips, and more! But the icing on the cake of this experience was the customer service.  The family and staff that run MEB are just lovely.  Besides Omur yogurt and the other sundries I usually stock up on when I make this trip, I discovered (thanks to a Yelp review) they stock cardamom coffee.  I love a lot of things, like MEB, as anyone may have ascertained by now, but among my top loves, are coffee and cardamom. Coffee and cardamom TOGETHER?! Where have I been?! Insert an Elaine Benes "GET OUT!" exclamation.  For tea lovers, there is black tea and cardamom.  I purchased this too, duh. When I inquired, I believe it was the owner, who guided me to the shelf where two varieties were sold.  These were finely ground and meant for Turkish coffee.  Verging on crestfallen, because I just have a regular coffee maker, I declined, but the gentleman did not stop there.  He offered to grind up a pound of medium roast with cardamom mixed in. Although it was an arduous trek in the cold and snow, when I made my coffee this morning, it was worth it. Not only did my apartment smell delicious, but the coffee was divine.Andersonville is so lucky to have such a gem.

24.description: I am crazy about this place.  I love the vegan pizzas.  It is so tasty and there are so many vegetables on it. I like that they put so many on it. The dough is great. When you heat it up, it is so delicious.  I think it's much better than ordering a vegetable pizza elsewhere. I also like the friendly man behind the counter of the pizzas.  You can also eat it not heated.  I sometimes take it to work, where a microwave is not available and it is still fantastic.  It's just as tasty.  The olives in the container are a terrific selection and taste great, and also the dark chocolate cherries, mixed fruit, and other selections they have are terrific to snack on.  I really love this place because it is one of the few places where I know whatever I get the quality is good and I don't have to worry.  I also know everything is fresh too. There are so many things to discover here.  When I'm not in a hurry, I'm going to take my time and really check out their other items because I keep getting the same things over again, which is not a bad thing, but I need to start tasting the other things like their different kinds of hummus, teas, and pies also.

7.description: One visit. Multiple yums. I needed preserved lemons for a dish I was making Christmas Eve.  Whole Paycheck was my first thought but then I thought I should check Yelp first.  I'm glad I did because  not only did I find I could purchase the preserved lemons here, but it looked like I could get more of the items I needed here as well.  The store is full of Middle eastern food staples as well as a counter/fridge for prepared items. My list:Preserved lemons Large grain couscousZaa'tar seasoningHummusFresh PitaDried fruitsPistachiosMy impulse buys:Baba GhannoujZaa'tar breadLamb and potato hand pie (2)Cheese and artichoke hand pie (1)feta cheeseolivesEverything I purchased was delicious. The hummus and baba ghannouj was well seasoned and flavorful. Hummus super smooth and creamy; the BG a little chunky but the perfect consistency for me. The hand pies were yummy and well-made--great crust and fillings. The cheese, fruits, nuts, olives were great quality as well. I love trying new foods and Zaa'tar was a great discovery for me. I needed the spice blend for a vinaigrette I was making and just about fell in love with it. I arrived there shortly after opening and the bread racks weren't filled yet.  I asked the friendly staff if there was more pita bread and they said it would be about 10 minutes.  My tip to you, if you have 10 minutes and can wait for the fresh pita, DO IT. because it was so very very good.  The aroma of fresh bread is heavenly and I didn't mind browsing the store while I waited for fresh pita. I already have the falafel sandwich on my list for my next visit as well as more baba ghannouj.  Love this store.

49.description: I came here on an empty stomach and couldn't decided what to get so I got an assortment. If you get one thing, get the spicy baba ganoush! I bought the small container of that and a big container of hummus and the eggplant dip. Both were good too but I really wished I had more of the spicy baba ganoush.  Also tried an eggplant pie, an olive, parsley, feta pie, sesame bread, pitas, olives, and honey cake. The only thing I didn't care for was the honey cake. Keep in mind, I had never had it before and didn't know what to expect.Prices are reasonable. The small dips are about $3 and larger size is $5. I think the pies are $1.75. They also have a great assortment of beans. I'm sure they have other stuff too but that is all that sticks out in my mind.

40.description: This place is fantastic! Was introduced to this wonderful store on a chilly afternoon. It's kind of hidden on a side street of Andersonville. Got a bottle of siracha, and more than a few of their "pizzas." They have a wide selection of various kinds of rice, seasonings, and a lot of pre-packaged salads.Not a place to get all of your grocery shopping done, but a definate option for picking up some great options for dinner!

53.description: Oh man, where to begin?! First of all, I'm not going to compare this place to Pars Persian Store up the road because Pars is more of a tea store with a little bit of groceries, while Middle East B&G is more of a grocer with a little bit of tea (though I do highly recommend Pars Persian).  Now that that's out of the way...For such a small corner-store this place has immense variety! There are several different types of filled pockets (meat & veggie), rice, genuine middle eastern yogurts, dips and spreads (including their hummus', which live up to the hype), nuts and seeds, dried fruits (including hard to find dried strawberries, which have healthfully replaced my wicked candy habit), spices and salts (did you know black salt exists?! well you do now!), desserts (baklavas, several varieties of butter cookies and pastries with pistachios, honey, and rosewater!).  They even sell Aleppo (bay leaf) soap, which is the first time I've seen it in the US - I've hunted everywhere for it!I can personally recommend their pita bread (made fresh daily without oils or preservatives), manaiesh thyme bread, mint tea, spicy hummus (hell, all of their varieties are delicious), tzatziki, house made smoked eggplant salad, cashew almond pumpkin seed clusters (gluten-free), pistachio nougat (mmm) and all of the aforementioned items above.In all honesty, I was never even that big a fan of middle eastern food before, but this grocer makes it so easy to create a quick, fresh, light, and healthy dinner that I'm HOOKED! I absolutely LOVE that the ingredients are clearly listen on the front label of their homemade and bulk products - it makes it so easy to shop.  The only negative aspect I can think of is that the place is a bit dusty at times, but as far as I can tell that's never effected the cleanliness of the food.

30.description: This place is fun to explore. I've bought flatbreads and chocolate baklava and both were tastey!

46.description: Love this place!!!  So fresh, delicious and authentic.  Wonderful freshly prepared foods and a fully stocked natural food market .  Who needs WHole F** Ds when you have this store in your neighborhood?  Also, friendly owner and staff and reasonable prices.  Support this wonderful local store!!!

1.description: Snack? Done.  Lunch?  Done.  Stuff for entertaining your guests?  Done. Ingredients for multiple dinner options?  Done!!Get:- anything from the back/east refrigerated section (baba ganouj, hummus, LENTIL SOUP, dolmas, guacamole, harissa, etc.) - anything from the falafel/savory pies/"pizzas," flatbreads counter- small fresh bread rolls and pita from the wall along the front windows by the door- pilaf with roasted vermicelli - red lentilsAffordable prices, always fresh baked items, friendly staff.

55.description: I do not live in Andersonville but I wish I do so that I could be closer to this gem! This place is big on variety and on quality.  There are few things I love more than a quality dip/spread and does this place ever have some of the best in the city! I love it so much I even buy them to bring with me when I go the suburbs to have dinner with the family.  Some people might be embarrassed showing up with food prepared by others and clearly purchased just minutes before heading out to a family gathering. But when it is hard to tear people away from the goods, I think anyone will look past taking the easy way out.

9.description: This authentic grocery store is so awesome.  It reminds me of the the places I visited while in Jerusalem.  It smelled so good from the first step into the store.  I love how the hummus, baba ganoush, dips, tapenades, cheeses, deli items, and other delicious and super healthy bakery goods are so natural with no preservatives.  You can get Hummus any way you like, spicy, dill, garlic, red pepper, you name it!  There are a variety of other natural dips which I can't wait to go back and try.  I was so thrilled by the variety of choices of super fresh bread!  I love my pita bread right out of the oven.  I am so happy to have stumbled apon this gem!  I know I will be back again for my middle eastern grocery shopping.

26.description: One visit. Multiple yums. I needed preserved lemons for a dish I was making Christmas Eve.  Whole Paycheck was my first thought but then I thought I should check Yelp first.  I'm glad I did because  not only did I find I could purchase the preserved lemons here, but it looked like I could get more of the items I needed here as well.  The store is full of Middle eastern food staples as well as a counter/fridge for prepared items. My list:Preserved lemons Large grain couscousZaa'tar seasoningHummusFresh PitaDried fruitsPistachiosMy impulse buys:Baba GhannoujZaa'tar breadLamb and potato hand pie (2)Cheese and artichoke hand pie (1)feta cheeseolivesEverything I purchased was delicious. The hummus and baba ghannouj was well seasoned and flavorful. Hummus super smooth and creamy; the BG a little chunky but the perfect consistency for me. The hand pies were yummy and well-made--great crust and fillings. The cheese, fruits, nuts, olives were great quality as well. I love trying new foods and Zaa'tar was a great discovery for me. I needed the spice blend for a vinaigrette I was making and just about fell in love with it. I arrived there shortly after opening and the bread racks weren't filled yet.  I asked the friendly staff if there was more pita bread and they said it would be about 10 minutes.  My tip to you, if you have 10 minutes and can wait for the fresh pita, DO IT. because it was so very very good.  The aroma of fresh bread is heavenly and I didn't mind browsing the store while I waited for fresh pita. I already have the falafel sandwich on my list for my next visit as well as more baba ghannouj.  Love this store.

25.description: This place deserves 5 stars for the spicy babaghanuge alone.  It no joke changed my life.  I like to buy a bunch of the savory pies (I've tried most of their varieties and haven't found a dud yet--favorites are the meat pie and the spinach with cheese) and dip them in the spicy babaghanuge.  Throw in a cup of their fresh lentil soup and you've got a mindblowingly yummy lunch!If I can tear myself away from the prepared foods part of the store, I'd love to scoop up some of their other items like spices, teas, etc.  Staff has always been friendly when I've been there.

12.description: I visit this place as often as possible and have dreams about the delicious savory baked goods! Have your coffee beans ground with cardamom! The loose tea mixes are better (IMO) than fancy tea houses and more affordable too. Butter beans, tabouli, hummus and other mixed dips or salads are delicious- great to take to dinner parties! Vegan friendly pizza, and gluten free friendly crackers. They are opening a restaurant next door and I am looking forward to it. The staff is always kind and attentive.

59.description: This place is so simple to review. JUST WALK IN AND BUY EVERYTHING!No seriously, it is just that good. Spicy Hummus is out of this world and Soups are home made and delicious.

21.description: Spinach cheese pies.  Years ago, I used to live in Hyde Park, and relished any trip to far-away Andersonville so I could get these spinach cheese pies.  And artichoke pies, and parsley olive pies... but the spinach cheese pies are the best (I don't eat meat, so possibly the meat pies are just as good).Then I moved away from Chicago and on my yearly-or-so return trips to Chicago, I would try to finagle a trip to the Middle Eastern Bakery so I could get more pies.And now I live within walking distance, and my life feels charmed.  For it's not just the savory pies that I have unlimited access to now, but the makings of a picnic or meal in with such little effort and such big flavors: multiple kinds of hummus and baba ghanoush, multiple kinds of fresh pita, tzatziki, lentil soup, olives, zaatar flat bread, cheeses, sweets, etc.At least stop in for a spinach cheese pie: they will warm it up for you if you ask, so you can eat it on your way out the door.  Also, if you're like me, you'll possibly walk away with sour cherry jam and preserved lemons, even though you only came in for a snack.

17.description: Great neighborhood gem that was recommended by a colleague, and I'm so glad I finally paid them a visit! They have every spice imaginable, as well as teas, pastries, pastas, and food to grab on the go, which I plan to try on my next trip. I was so glad to find some of the teas and honeys, and hazelnut spreads that I grew so fond of when visiting Istanbul a few years ago, so this place is a must if you're looking for ingredients/items that aren't carried by grocery chains.

10.description: We recently ordered all the food for what we called my mom's "Bon Voyage Party" - her memorial service  -- from the Middle Eastern Bakery. Mom's happiest time of her life was when she and my dad lived in the Middle East when he was in the service, and Middle Eastern food always was one of the most visceral ways she connected to that time of her life. Two years ago, I moved her to Chicago because her Alzheimer's disease was progressing to the point she needed round the clock care - but also because I wanted her to experience some of the greater ethnic diversity that Chicago had to offer. One of the first places I took her in Chicago was the Middle Eastern Bakery, and she fell in love with it, and with the people, who were extremely kind to her. I knew her send-off couldn't be catered by anyone else! We got food for 45, and ended up with three times what we needed, for less than 300! And everyone was SO nice. Plus, this is the best Middle Eastern food I've had in Chicago -- they don't do everything, but what they do is SUPERB. AND they won over many of the party-goers to Middle Eastern cuisine. Thank you for helping my mom go out in the style she deserved, and would have wanted.

5.description: Been shopping here for over 30 years. I'm Lebanese, know middle eastern cuisine. No other me grocery close except Feyrouz Bakery. Quality, consistency, variety, taste just way better than anywhere else. My favorites;  French feta, garlic hummus, many dif esfihas, uncooked felafel to make fresh at home, their meat grape leaves, Zdan yogurt, etc.

3.description: Yummy olives, dips, spreads, bread, cheese, and sweet treats. Check out the cured Turkish black olives in particular. They have a wide assortment of spices, lentils, rice, and other pantry staples too. Staff are very nice and helpful. I can't wait until they open the attached restaurant!!

35.description: This my favorite grocery. From staple items ( grains, spices, coffee) to prepared foods I have never been disappointed. Great prices too. I have turned my friends on to this spot and now we all sing their praises. If you haven't stopped in it is a must for a quick lunch or to stock your pantry.

19.description: This place deserves 5 stars for the spicy babaghanuge alone.  It no joke changed my life.  I like to buy a bunch of the savory pies (I've tried most of their varieties and haven't found a dud yet--favorites are the meat pie and the spinach with cheese) and dip them in the spicy babaghanuge.  Throw in a cup of their fresh lentil soup and you've got a mindblowingly yummy lunch!If I can tear myself away from the prepared foods part of the store, I'd love to scoop up some of their other items like spices, teas, etc.  Staff has always been friendly when I've been there.

28.description: I've been stopping by Middle East Bakery and Grocery about once a month for over three years.  The foods I like have been consistently good, and I've only noticed the price going up on their pies.The place is on the smaller side, which is fine, because I can buy my staple goods and am out in time to catch the next bus.  I regularly get the "vegan pizza" and thyme "pizza", both of which are by the pies.  I also like the garlic hummus and Jerusalem salad, which are refrigerated.  In addition, the freshly made pitas and breads are good, as are the pita chips.  They also have a large variety of dried spices, lentils, fruits, and coffee beans.  If you're near Andersonville, you have to check this place out!

45.description: Spicy baba gaboush: WOW to die forGreat foods, so reasonable and like being in an intimate neighborhood.Love it

33.description: I love this place.  Everything is so good!! I love the spinach Kibbi!

43.description: First of all, there is a credit card minimum of $7. This is important because you have to *try* to spend that much here.  Second of all, there are few other places where you'll get a lunch that good for that cheap.  I had a spinach pie and a chicken pie, each of which checks in under $2. Both were amazing, although the spinach left a longer lasting impression.  You can also get homemade pitas, which are WAY better and WAY cheaper than store brand. (5/$1.45. Really.) It's a little bit out of the way, but if you're in A-ville, make the stop.

2.description: I've been here many times for the bread , they have good arabic bread but one time I was hungry and I ordered cheese and oliv e pies ,I took them and went home when I started eating I was  surprised they were both  spinach Pies and I had severe diarrhea after eating it . It's weird the guy who was standing there doesn't know what inside the pies !!! I think their Falafel and Pies are old and not clean .Some stuff are overpriced , I can find them cheaper in other middle eastern groceries.Otherwise it would be a good place for shopping don't try to eat from them .My one star for the fresh bread only .

18.description: Falafel sandwich, you complete me. Love the hand pies and the fact that I can never remember which hand pie (olive or artichoke) is which in the bag. It is like the most successful and tasty game of Russian roulette ever. Yep, I'm a rebel living on the edge.

41.description: This place is fantastic!  amazing foods.  try all the pies, and the dill Hummus is The Best I've ever had.  Seriously dangerous.  Great candies, dried fruit, nuts and jordan almonds. My one complaint, is that the prices of nuts and fruits are a little high.  Perhaps the best thing about this place is the family that runs it.  Terrific people and real pillars of Andersonville.

52.description: Who knew so many varieties of lentils existed?Who knew that I'd enjoy all of them?

50.description: I keep making the drive here for their excellent hummous and other fresh  dips. Thanks fellow Yeelpers for this exvellent recommendation!

4.description: I always enjoy coming here,  especially for the delicious house blended middle eastern and other regional spice blends.  It still has a small grocery store feel despite the emergence of the incredibly more trendy and upscale Andersonville neighborhood. They are expanding into the building next door,  previously the Algerian Crepe place (which I loved and miss) and I suspect they will expand their selections spruce up their store in the process. Can't wait.

6.description: I now live in Albany Park and I am able to get most of the stuff closer to home.  But I don't have a place that makes pies like they do.  Their baked goods are why I make the trek to Foster.  They have decent hummus, but there are better places to get hummus in the city.  But the baked goods...yummmmm!  Oh yeah, and he makes a mean harrissa, imam Bayildi, and tapenade!

22.description: I have been going to the Middle Eastern bakery for practically my whole life. In that time I don't think their food has changed at all, and why should it? It's already some of the best (and cheapest and freshest) middle eastern food in the city. My personal faves are the tabouleh, the baba ganough, and the dolmades. They also sell whole coffee beans, basic groceries, and fresh olives and cheese. So glad they are expanding!!

15.description: I'm a huge fan of this place. Their pastries pies are all delicious and at $2 each you can't go wrong. They have a wide variety of spices and that small neighborhood store vibe. Love it!!

57.description: Clean, well-stocked across the street from the taste of lebanon and is situated in a happening neighborhood. The only complaint is the prices here is higher than other middle eastern grocer I have been to in Chicago.

20.description: Stopped in yesterday to pick up some goodies.  The love hasn't died and in fact it's stronger than ever.  Try the lentil soup that's in the refrigerator case.  It's delightfully light, clean and lemony.  The lemony artichoke spread is addictive and wonderful on pita bread or pita chips.   I also got the lentil pie, as well as the spinach and onion pie.  So much portable tastiness in a neat little pocket.  I'm looking forward to the cafe opening, which they said should be open early summer.   It will be a great addition to the corner of Foster and Clark!

36.description: a little taste of dubai-home...a patron before my expat experience in the middle east,  i now have a special place in my heart for middle east bakery and grocery.  simple, straightforward name offering complex, authentic flavors.  i must add that you need NEED to also try their manakeesh (bread with zaatar and cheese).  it rivals some i've had overseas.  i can eat the spinach kibbeh by the boatload.  it was actually near impossible to find this treat overseas - probably because it's traditionally made with meat - so i'm so very grateful to middle east bakery for treating us vegetarians!

14.description: Spinach cheese pies.  Years ago, I used to live in Hyde Park, and relished any trip to far-away Andersonville so I could get these spinach cheese pies.  And artichoke pies, and parsley olive pies... but the spinach cheese pies are the best (I don't eat meat, so possibly the meat pies are just as good).Then I moved away from Chicago and on my yearly-or-so return trips to Chicago, I would try to finagle a trip to the Middle Eastern Bakery so I could get more pies.And now I live within walking distance, and my life feels charmed.  For it's not just the savory pies that I have unlimited access to now, but the makings of a picnic or meal in with such little effort and such big flavors: multiple kinds of hummus and baba ghanoush, multiple kinds of fresh pita, tzatziki, lentil soup, olives, zaatar flat bread, cheeses, sweets, etc.At least stop in for a spinach cheese pie: they will warm it up for you if you ask, so you can eat it on your way out the door.  Also, if you're like me, you'll possibly walk away with sour cherry jam and preserved lemons, even though you only came in for a snack.

58.description: Intended to check out all the nearby coffee shops when I visited my brother, but ended up coming back here every day! I appreciate a good Americano, and Dollop knows how to make one. It's rare that I'll inquire about the brand of coffee, just because I find it hard to distinguish among all the great espresso out there. But here I was so impressed that I needed to know the beans they were using (Metropolis), and ended up buying a bag to take to SF. The breakfast food was good, but not as memorable as the coffee. Nice open space with many seating options and plenty of outlets. This will be my go-to spot for getting coffee & working remotely whenever I visit Chicago.

56.description: Me and my fiancé used to go here all the time. Sadly we just moved neighborhoods and have not found a coffee shop we like as much as Dollop. The atmosphere is really nice, it has a cool back room with couches which is perfect for reading and drinking coffee. They have really good coffee, snacks and the staff is nice too. Really chill and helpful. If you haven't been, you should definitely give it a shot.

29.description: You walk into this cozy, quaint shop, and there's a Tetris arcade game to your right.  A man reading an actual book with pages in front of you. Someone drinking their coffee and eating 2 croissants while gazing out the window.  Then, to top the entire experience off, you order a small coffee, that actually comes out small. Wow. Perfection. I only wish I lived closer.

42.description: The Buena Park Dollop has been my go-to local coffee haunt for more than a year. We've had some ups and downs, so I thought it was time to write a review.Dollop has a lot going for it. There's lots of seating inside, and it has a quirky, casual vibe that characterizes few other local establishments -- it's got exposed brick walls, local art, and mismatched furniture. The stuff coming through the sound system is always a musical grab bag -- I don't like all of it, but the variety adds to Dollop's charm. There's a good variety of drinks and food (though I feel like the pastry selection has been veering toward vegan/gluten-free recently...none of it ever looks that appetizing anymore), and the coffee is good. My faves include the honey cinnamon latte, the Halloween seasonal spooky mocha, and the beach babe iced coconut latte. They serve Metropolis coffee, so it's pretty good stuff. I love the turkey sandwich and would gladly eat it every day. Prices are reasonable. The free wifi is touch-and-go.There are a few reasons for my three-star rating: 1. Through no fault of Dollop's own, temperature regulation is difficult during winter months. I typically head to Dollop on weekdays, and last winter it was so cold that I couldn't concentrate on my work. I always try to bag the seat in the back next to the radiator, but this didn't really help. It's just a really big place. Notably, the staff wear winter hats and scarves during these hours. Brrrr! Conversely, on weekends when the crowd is more bumpin', it gets pretty warm and, if it's been raining, muggy.2. Dollop suffers from a severe lack of safely positioned power outlets. Each wall socket has a power strip that serves the nearest 6-8 customers, so getting back to that seat next to the radiator poses a major trip hazard. It's really dangerous, and I'm always afraid that I'm going to bite it when I'm carrying my very full coffee.3. Most significantly, I get weird vibes from the staff. I go there a lot, and they don't go out of their way to be gregarious. A smile and a, "Hey, how's it going?" wouldn't go amiss. Also, there are things that the staff have done that border on condescending. I followed them on Twitter for a while, and they posted a picture of a piece of gum stuck to a plate with a caption that was something like: "You guys. This is unacceptable." Um...is it not someone's job to do the dishes? In the bathroom there used to be a handwritten sign that said something like: "If you're grown up enough to drink coffee, you're grown up enough to throw your paper towels in the trash can. Dollop *Heart*s you more when you do the right thing." I understand that it can be irritating when people are slobs, but I don't really enjoy being passive-aggressively lumped into the slob category. Plus, if I wanted to be treated like a misbehaving child, customer service at Chase bank is only a phone call away.After this sign went up, I've been willing to travel the extra distance to go to Metropolis in Edgewater where the staff are friendly and the electrical outlets are less precarious.

23.description: Dollop, oh Dollop.  How can I write an objective review?  You symbolize the single life to me.  A time of living in the City, with fewer responsibilities.  A time when I could wake up late on Sunday, and wile away the day with the newspaper.  I think I had a couple of first and only dates here.  Perhaps  choosing to work from here today is both sweetly nostalgic and somewhat masochistic.  We cannot recapture our youth.  To get down to the important stuff, the coffee and pastries are both quite good.  Not setting the world on fire good, but solid.  Dollop gets an extra star for nearly perfect decor, with a wonderful tucked-away back room.  This is one of the best places to hang out in Buena Park, a small neighborhood that is not quite Uptown or Lakeview.  Now I will get back to living in the present moment.

47.description: This is one of the best independent coffee shops in all of Chicago. The coffee is great. The neighborhood location is gorgeous. The staff is consistently friendly and helpful. It can get crowded on the weekends but there's always a comfy place to camp. Free wife of course. Worth going out of your way for!
